Subparagraph.Text: in any number of articles exceeding 1 000 for explosives subject to special provision 85 or 86.

Heading.TitleText: Class 2, Gases, or Ammonia Solutions (Class 8) in Refrigerating Machines Exemption

Section.Text: Parts 3 to 10 and 17 do not apply to UN2857, REFRIGERATING MACHINES, and refrigerating machine components containing gases included in Class 2.2 or UN2672, AMMONIA SOLUTION, if the quantity of gas has a mass that is less than or equal to 12 kg and the quantity of ammonia solution is less than or equal to 12 L.

Heading.TitleText: Class 2, Gases, that May Be Identified as UN1075, LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS

Subsection.Text: The following dangerous goods may be identified by the UN number UN1075 and the shipping name LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GASES instead of the UN number and shipping name identified for them:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: UN1011, BUTANE;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: UN1012, BUTYLENE;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: UN1055, ISOBUTYLENE;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: UN1077, PROPYLENE;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: UN1969, ISOBUTANE; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: UN1978, PROPANE.

Subsection.Text: The shipping name of the dangerous goods listed in paragraphs (1)(a) to (f) may be shown on the shipping document, in parentheses, following the words “LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GASES”.

If either UN1077, PROPYLENE, or UN1978, PROPANE, is to be transported on a road vehicle or railway vehicle on board a vessel and is identified as LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GASES on the shipping document in accordance with subsection (1), the shipping name PROPYLENE or PROPANE, as appropriate, must be shown on the shipping document, in parentheses, following the words “LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GASES”.

Heading.TitleText: Class 2, Gases, Absolute Pressure between 101.3 kPa and 280 kPa

Section.Text: Gases that are at an absolute pressure between 101.3 kPa and 280 kPa at 20°C, other than gases included in Class 2.1 or Class 2.3, may be handled, offered for transport or transported on a road vehicle, a railway vehicle or a vessel on a domestic voyage as Class 2.2, Non-flammable, Non-toxic gas. In that case, the requirements of these Regulations that relate to gases included in Class 2.2 must be complied with.

Heading.TitleText: Class 2, Gases, in Small Means of Containment Exemption

Section.Text: Part 3 (Documentation) and Part 6 (Training) do not apply to dangerous goods that are transported in one or more small means of containment on a road vehicle solely on land if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the dangerous goods are

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1001, ACETYLENE, DISSOLVED,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1002, AIR, COMPRESSED,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1006, ARGON, COMPRESSED,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1013, CARBON DIOXIDE,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1060, METHYLACETYLENE AND PROPADIENE MIXTURE, STABILIZED,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1066, NITROGEN, COMPRESSED,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1072, OXYGEN, COMPRESSED, or

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1978, PROPANE;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the dangerous goods are contained in no more than five small means of containment;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the gross mass of the dangerous goods is less than or equal to 500 kg; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the labels displayed on the small means of containment can be seen from outside the road vehicle.

Section.Text: Part 3 (Documentation), Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks), Part 5 (Means of Containment), Part 6 (Training), Part 7 (Emergency Response Assistance Plan), Part 9 (Road) and Part 10 (Rail) do not apply to the handling, offering for transport or transporting of dangerous goods included in Class 3, Flammable Liquids, on a road vehicle, a railway vehicle or a vessel on a domestic voyage if the dangerous goods

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have no subsidiary class;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are included in Packing Group III and have a flash point greater than 37.8°C; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: are in one or more small means of containment designed, constructed, filled, closed, secured and maintained so that under normal conditions of transport, including handling, there will be no release of the dangerous goods that could endanger public safety.

Heading.TitleText: Class 3, Flammable Liquids, Flash Point Greater Than 60°C but Less Than or Equal to 93°C

Section.Text: Despite section 6.1 of the Act and section 4.2 of Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks) of these Regulations, substances that have a flash point greater than 60°C but less than or equal to 93°C may be transported on a road vehicle, on a railway vehicle or on a vessel on a domestic voyage as Class 3, Flammable Liquids, Packing Group III. In that case, the requirements of these Regulations, except paragraph 7.2(1)(f) of Part 7 (Emergency Response Assistance Plan), that relate to flammable liquids that have a flash point less than or equal to 60°C must be complied with.

Heading.TitleText: UN1202, DIESEL FUEL, or UN1203, GASOLINE, Exemption

Section.Text: Part 3 (Documentation), the UN number requirements in sections 4.12 and 4.15.2 of Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks) and Part 6 (Training) do not apply to the offering for transport, handling or transporting on a road vehicle of dangerous goods that are UN1202, DIESEL FUEL or UN1203, GASOLINE, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the dangerous goods are in one or more means of containment, each of which is visible from outside the road vehicle and each of which has displayed on it

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the label or placard required for the dangerous goods by Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks), or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if a side or end of the means of containment is not visible from outside the road vehicle, the label or placard required for the dangerous goods by Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks) on a side or end that is visible from outside the road vehicle;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: each means of containment is secured to the road vehicle so that the required label or at least one of the required placards displayed on it is visible from outside the road vehicle during transport; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the total capacity of all the means of containment is less than or equal to 2 000 L.

Heading.TitleText: Class 3, Flammable Liquids, Alcoholic Beverage and Aqueous Solution of Alcohol Exemption

Section.Text: Part 3 (Documentation), Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks), Part 5 (Means of Containment), Part 6 (Training), Part 7 (Emergency Response Assistance Plan), Part 8 (Reporting Requirements), Part 9 (Road) and Part 10 (Rail) do not apply to the handling, offering for transport or transporting on a road vehicle, a railway vehicle or a vessel on a domestic voyage of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an alcoholic beverage if the alcoholic beverage

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: contains alcohol that is less than or equal to 24% by volume,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is included in Packing Group II and is in a means of containment with a capacity that is less than or equal to 5 L, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: is included in Packing Group III and is in a means of containment with a capacity that is less than or equal to 250 L; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an aqueous solution of alcohol if the aqueous solution has a flash point greater than 23°C and

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: contains alcohol that is less than or equal to 50% by volume and at least 50% by volume of a substance that is not dangerous goods, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is contained in a small means of containment.

Section.Text: Part 3 (Documentation), Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks), Part 5 (Means of Containment), Part 6 (Training), Part 7 (Emergency Response Assistance Plan), Part 8 (Reporting Requirements), Part 9 (Road) and Part 10 (Rail) do not apply to the handling, offering for transport or transporting of a polyester resin kit that consists of a substance included in Class 3, Packing Group II or III and a substance included in Class 5.2, Type D, E or F that does not require temperature control if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the kit is in transport on a road vehicle, a railway vehicle or a vessel on a domestic voyage;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the gross mass of the kit is less than or equal to 30 kg;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of Class 3 substance in the kit is less than or equal to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 1 L for Packing Group II substances, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 5 L for Packing Group III substances; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of Class 5.2 substance in the kit is less than or equal to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: 125 mL for liquids, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 500 g for solids.

Heading.TitleText: Class 6.2, Infectious Substances, UN3373, BIOLOGICAL SUBSTANCE, CATEGORY B Exemption

Section.Text: Parts 3 and 4, except section 4.22.1, and Part 17 do not apply to the offering for transport, handling or transporting of infectious substances that are included in Category B if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one external surface of the means of containment for the substances measures at least 100 mm × 100 mm;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the means of containment is in compliance with Part 5 (Means of Containment) and has displayed on the external surface

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the mark illustrated in Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks) for infectious substances included in Category B, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the shipping name, on a contrasting background, next to the mark in letters at least 6 mm high; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the 24-hour telephone number required under paragraph 3.5(1)(f) is displayed next to the shipping name on the means of containment.

Section.Text: Parts 3 to 8 and 17 do not apply to the offering for transport, handling or transporting of biological products if they

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are prepared in accordance with the requirements set out under the Food and Drugs Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are in a means of containment that is designed, constructed, filled, closed, secured and maintained so that under normal conditions of transport, including handling, there will be no release of the dangerous goods that could endanger public safety; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: are in a means of containment that is marked with the words “Biological Product” or “Produit biologique” in black letters at least 6 mm high on a contrasting background.

Heading.TitleText: Human or Animal Specimens Believed Not to Contain Infectious Substances Exemption

Subsection.Text: Parts 3 to 8 and 17 do not apply to the offering for transport, handling or transporting of human or animal specimens that are reasonably believed not to contain infectious substances.

The human or animal specimens referred to in subsection (1) must be in a means of containment that is marked with the words “Exempt Human Specimen” or “spécimen humain exempté” or “Exempt Animal Specimen” or “spécimen animal exempté” and that is designed, constructed, filled, closed, secured and maintained so that under normal conditions of transport, including handling, there will be no release of the specimen.

Heading.TitleText: Tissues or Organs for Transplant Exemption

Section.Text: These Regulations do not apply to the offering for transport, handling or transport of tissues or organs for transplant.

Subsection.Text: Parts 3 to 8 and 17 do not apply to the offering for transport, handling or transporting of blood or blood components that are intended for transfusion or for the preparation of blood products and are reasonably believed not to contain infectious substances.

The blood or blood components referred to in subsection (1) must be in a means of containment that is designed, constructed, filled, closed, secured and maintained so that under normal conditions of transport, including handling, there will be no release of the blood or blood components.

Section.Text: Part 3, sections 4.10 to 4.12 and Parts 5 to 8 and 17 do not apply to the offering for transport, handling or transporting of dangerous goods that are medical waste or clinical waste if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the dangerous goods are UN3291, (BIO) MEDICAL WASTE, N.O.S.;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the dangerous goods are in a means of containment that is in compliance with CGSB-43.125; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the following information is displayed on the means of containment:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the biohazard symbol; and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the word “BIOHAZARD” or “BIORISQUE”.

Section.Text: Parts 3 to 7, 9 to 12 and 17 do not apply to the offering for transport, handling or transporting of dangerous goods included in Class 7 if the dangerous goods

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: satisfy the conditions in the Packaging and Transport of Nuclear Substances Regulations to be transported in an excepted package;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are in an excepted package; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: are accompanied by a document that includes the shipping name and UN number of the radioactive materials.

Heading.TitleText: Residue of Dangerous Goods in a Drum Exemption

Section.Text: Part 2 (Classification), Part 3 (Documentation), Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks), and Part 7 (Emergency Response Assistance Plan) do not apply to a residue of dangerous goods contained in a drum that is in transport on a road vehicle, a railway vehicle or a vessel on a domestic voyage, except for dangerous goods included in Packing Group I or contained in a drum otherwise requiring a label for Class 1, 4.3, 6.2 or 7, if

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the drum is being transported for the purpose of reconditioning or reuse in accordance with section 5.12 of Part 5 (Means of Containment);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: when more than 10 drums are on the road vehicle or on the railway vehicle, the road vehicle or railway vehicle has displayed on it the DANGER placard in accordance with Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks); and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the drums are accompanied by a document that includes the following information:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the primary class of each residue and the words “Residue Drum(s)” or “fût(s) de résidu” when the primary class can be reasonably determined, preceded by the number of drums containing dangerous goods with that primary class, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the words “Residue Drum(s) – Content(s) Unknown” or “fût(s) de résidu – contenu inconnu” if there are any residues for which the primary class cannot be reasonably determined, preceded by the number of drums containing the residues.

Section.Text: These Regulations, except for subsection 3.5(3) of Part 3 (Documentation) and section 4.21 of Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks), do not apply to a means of containment, or the contents of a means of containment, that is being fumigated with dangerous goods and that is in transport if the fumigant is the only dangerous goods in transport in the means of containment.

Part 3 (Documentation) and Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks) do not apply to substances that are classified as marine pollutants in accordance with section 2.43 of Part 2 (Classification) if they are in transport solely on land by road vehicle or railway vehicle. However, substances may be identified as marine pollutants on a shipping document and the required dangerous goods safety marks may be displayed when they are in transport by road or railway vehicle.
These Regulations do not apply to the following dangerous goods:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ammoniating fertilizer solutions with an absolute pressure of ammonia less than or equal to 276 kPa at 41°C;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: antimony oxides and antimony sulphides with 0.5% or less arsenic by mass;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: charcoal or carbons that are

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: non-activated carbon blacks of mineral origin,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: carbons made by a steam activation process, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: activated or non-activated carbons that pass the self-heating test for carbon in section 33.3.1.3.3 of the Manual of Tests and Criteria;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: cinnabar;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: cyclohexanone peroxides with 70% or more inert inorganic solid, by mass;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: Di-4-chlorobenzoyl peroxide or p-chlorobenzoyl peroxide with 70% or more inert inorganic solid, by mass;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: 1,3-Di-(2-tert-butylperoxyisopropyl) benzene or 1,4-Di-(2-tert-butylperoxyisopropyl) benzene, or mixtures of both, 60% or more, by mass, of which consists of an inert solid, if the substance is in a means of containment in a total quantity less than or equal to 200 kg;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: dibenzoyl peroxide or benzoyl peroxide that is in a concentration less than 35.5%, by mass, with finely ground starch, calcium sulphate dihydrate or dicalcium phosphate dihydrate, or that is in a concentration less than 30%, by mass, with 70% or more, by mass, inert solid;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: dicumyl peroxide with 60% or more inert inorganic solid, by mass;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: ferricyanides and ferrocyanides;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: fish-meal that is acidified and is wetted with 40% or more water, by mass;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: sodium dichloroisocyanurate dihydrate;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: solvent extracted soya bean meal free of flammable solvent and containing 1.5% or less oil, by mass, and 11% or less moisture, by mass; or

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: wood or wood products treated with wood preservatives.

Section.Text: Subsections 5.10(1) and (2) and Part 17 do not apply to the offering for transport, handling or transporting of UN1044, FIRE EXTINGUISHERS, if the fire extinguishers

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: do not contain dangerous goods included in Class 2.3, Class 6.1 or Class 8;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are contained in an outer means of containment;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have a capacity less than 18 L or, if they contain liquefied gas, a capacity less than 0.6 L;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: have an internal pressure less than or equal to 1 650 kPa at 21°C; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: are manufactured, tested, maintained, marked and used in accordance with ULC Standard S504, ULC Standard S507, ULC Standard S512 or ULC Standard S554.

Section.Text: These Regulations, except for Part 8 (Reporting Requirements), do not apply to dangerous goods required for patient care on an aircraft if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the aircraft is configured as an air ambulance and is used only as an air ambulance;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the transport of the dangerous goods is not forbidden in Schedule 1, Schedule 3 or the ICAO Technical Instructions;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the dangerous goods are under the control of a health care professional or a person who is trained in accordance with Part 6 (Training);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: dangerous goods included in Class 2, Gases, they are in one or more small means of containment in compliance with the requirements for transporting gases in Part 5 (Means of Containment), or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: dangerous goods not included in Class 2, Gases, they are in one or more small means of containment designed, constructed, filled, closed, secured and maintained so that under normal conditions of transport, including handling, there will be no accidental release of the dangerous goods that could endanger public safety; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the means of containment are secured to prevent unintended movement during transport.

Subsection.Text: Subsection 5.1(1) and Section 5.10 of Part 5 (Means of Containment) do not apply to the handling, offering for transport or transporting of dangerous goods in a cylinder on a road vehicle or an aircraft if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the cylinder is from or for a vessel or an aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the cylinder is transported solely for the purpose of refilling, exchanging or requalification;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the cylinder is accompanied by a shipping document that includes the words “Cylinder in transport for purpose of refilling, exchanging or requalification in compliance with section 1.49 of the TDGR” or “Bouteille à gaz en transport aux fins de remplissage, d’échange ou de requalification en conformité avec l’article 1.49 du RTMD”;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the cylinder is closed and secured so that under normal conditions of transport, including handling, there will be no release of the dangerous goods that could endanger public safety;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a cylinder from or for a vessel that is a Canadian vessel as defined in section 2 of the Canada Shipping Act, 2001, the cylinder conforms, as applicable, to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the Fire Detection and Extinguishing Equipment Regulations, as they read immediately before being repealed,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the Life Saving Equipment Regulations,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the Large Fishing Vessel Inspection Regulations,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the Fishing Vessel Safety Regulations,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the Small Vessel Regulations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the Vessel Fire Safety Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a cylinder from or for a vessel that is a foreign vessel as defined in section 2 of the Canada Shipping Act, 2001 and that is a Safety Convention vessel as defined in that section, the cylinder is used for a purpose related to the operation or navigation of the vessel, including a life-saving or emergency purpose; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a cylinder from or for an aircraft, a flight authority, as defined in subsection 101.01(1) of the Canadian Aviation Regulations, has been issued in respect of the aircraft and the cylinder serves an aeronautical purpose, including a life-saving or emergency purpose.

Subsection.Text: When the cylinder has been requalified or filled, the exemption set out in subsection (1) applies only if the cylinder was requalified in accordance with clause 6.5.1(b) of CSA B340 and filled in compliance with clause 6.5.1(c) of CSA B340.

Sections 5.1, 5.2 and 5.5 and subsection 5.10(1) do not apply to the offering for transport, handling or transport of UN1978, PROPANE, in a cylinder on a road vehicle, a railway vehicle or a ship on a domestic voyage if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the cylinder is for use in a hot air balloon and is marked clearly and visibly, in letters at least 5 mm high, with the words “FOR USE IN HOT AIR BALLOONS ONLY” or “POUR UTILISATION DANS LES BALLONS SEULEMENT”;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a flight authority, as defined in subsection 101.01(1) of the Canadian Aviation Regulations, has been issued in respect of the hot air balloon;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the cylinder is designed, constructed, filled, closed, secured and maintained so that under normal conditions of transport, including handling, there will be no release of dangerous goods that could endanger public safety;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: subject to paragraph (e), the cylinder

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is manufactured, selected and used in accordance with CSA B340, except clause 5.3.1.4 of that standard,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is manufactured, selected and used in accordance with CSA B342,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: is manufactured, selected and used in accordance with 49 CFR and, in the case of a requalified cylinder, is marked with the requalification markings required by CSA B339 or 49 CFR,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: is manufactured and selected in accordance with the ADR, is marked with the symbol π (Pi) in accordance with the TPED and is used in accordance with clauses 4.1.1.2, 4.1.3, 4.1.4, 4.2, 4.3.1, 4.3.2, 4.3.7, 4.3.8, 4.3.9, 5.1.1, 5.1.2, 5.1.3(b) to (e), 5.1.8 and 5.3.1.1 of CSA B340, or

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: was manufactured before January 1, 2017, and is used in accordance with clauses 4.1.1.2, 4.1.3, 4.1.4, 4.2, 4.3.1, 4.3.2, 4.3.7, 4.3.8, 4.3.9, 5.1.1, 5.1.2, 5.1.3(b) to (e), 5.1.8 and 5.3.1.1 of CSA B340; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the liquid phase of the propane is less than or equal to 85% of the capacity of the cylinder at 15°C.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subparagraph (1)(d)(iv), ADR means the European Agreement concerning the International Carriage of Dangerous Goods by Road, published by the United Nations, as amended from time to time and TPED means the Transportable Pressure Equipment Directive, Directive 2010/35/EU, June 16, 2010, published by the Council of the European Union.
Subject to subsection (4), a cylinder referred to in subparagraph (1)(d)(iv) or (v) must be requalified within

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 10 years after its date of manufacture; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 10 years after its most recent requalification date as marked on the cylinder.

Subsection.Text: A cylinder that must be requalified on or before January 1, 2018 may be requalified within a 12-month grace period that starts on the day on which this section comes into force.
When it is requalified, a cylinder referred to in subparagraph (1)(d)(iv) or (v) must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be requalified with a proof pressure retest and an internal and external visual inspection in accordance with clause 24 of CSA B339 by a facility that holds a valid certificate of registration referred to in clause 25.3 of CSA B339; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be subjected to a periodic inspection and test in accordance with clause 19 of CSA B341.

Heading.TitleText: Determining When Substances Are Dangerous Goods

Section.Text: A substance is dangerous goods when

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it is listed by name in Schedule 1 and is in any form, state or concentration that meets the criteria in this Part for inclusion in at least one of the nine classes of dangerous goods; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is not listed by name in Schedule 1 but meets the criteria in this Part for inclusion in at least one of the nine classes of dangerous goods.

Subsection.Text: Before allowing a carrier to take possession of dangerous goods for transport, the consignor must determine the classification of the dangerous goods in accordance with this Part.
When importing dangerous goods into Canada, the consignor must ensure that they have the correct classification before they are transported in Canada.
A consignor must use the following classifications:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for substances included in Class 1, Explosives, the classification determined in accordance with the Explosives Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for radioactive materials, the classification determined in accordance with the Packaging and Transport of Nuclear Substances Regulations.

Subsection.Text: For substances included in Class 6.2, Infectious Substances, a consignor may use a classification determined by the Public Health Agency of Canada or the Canadian Food Inspection Agency.

A consignor may use the appropriate classification in the ICAO Technical Instructions, the IMDG Code or the UN Recommendations to transport dangerous goods within Canada by a road vehicle, a railway vehicle or a vessel on a domestic voyage if these Regulations or the document from which the classification is taken does not forbid their transport.

If an error in classification is noticed or if there are reasonable grounds to suspect an error in classification, the consignor must not allow a carrier to take possession of the dangerous goods for transport until the classification has been verified or corrected.

A carrier who notices an error in classification or has reasonable grounds to suspect an error in classification while the dangerous goods are in transport must advise the consignor and must stop transporting the dangerous goods until the consignor verifies or corrects the classification. The consignor must immediately verify or correct the classification and ensure that the carrier is provided with the verified or corrected classification.

A consignor who allows a carrier to take possession of dangerous goods for transport or who imports dangerous goods into Canada must, during a five-year period that begins on the date that appears on the shipping document, make a proof of classification available to the Minister on reasonable notice given by the Minister.
For the purposes of this section, a proof of classification is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a test report;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a lab report; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a document that explains how the dangerous goods were classified.

Subsection.Text: A proof of classification must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the dangerous goods were classified;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the technical name of the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the classification of the dangerous goods; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the classification method used under this Part or under Chapter 2 of the UN Recommendations.

Heading.TitleText: Classifying Substances That Are Listed by Name in Schedule 1

Section.Text: If a name of dangerous goods is shown as a shipping name in column 2 of Schedule 1, that name must be used as the shipping name. That shipping name and the corresponding data for that shipping name in columns 1, 3 and 4 of Schedule 1 must be used as the classification of the dangerous goods.

Heading.TitleText: Classifying Substances That Are Included in Only One Class and One Packing Group

Section.Text: If, in accordance with the criteria and tests in this Part, a substance is included in only one class and one packing group, the substance is dangerous goods and the shipping name in column 2 of Schedule 1 that most precisely describes the dangerous goods and that is most consistent with the class and the packing group determined by the criteria and tests must be selected as the shipping name. That shipping name and the corresponding data for that shipping name in columns 1, 3 and 4 of Schedule 1 must be used as the classification of the dangerous goods.

Heading.TitleText: Classifying Substances That Are Included in More Than One Class or Packing Group

Section.Text: If, in accordance with the criteria and tests in this Part, a substance meets the criteria for inclusion in more than one class or packing group, the substance is dangerous goods and its classification is determined in the following manner:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the classes in which the dangerous goods are included are ranked in order of precedence in accordance with section 2.8 to determine the primary class and the potential subsidiary class or classes;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the potential packing group is the one with the lowest roman numeral;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the shipping name in column 2 of Schedule 1 that most precisely describes the dangerous goods and for which the corresponding data in columns 1, 3 and 4 are the most consistent with the primary class, the potential subsidiary class or classes and the potential packing group is selected; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the shipping name and the corresponding data in columns 1, 3 and 4 of Schedule 1 are used as the classification of the dangerous goods.

Heading.TitleText: Descriptive Text Following a Shipping Name

Section.Text: When applying section 2.4 or 2.5, the descriptive text written in lower case letters following a shipping name must be used in determining the shipping name that most precisely describes the dangerous goods.

A mixture or solution of substances that are not dangerous goods and one substance that is dangerous goods and that is listed by name in Schedule 1 has the classification shown for the dangerous goods in that Schedule if the mixture or solution is still dangerous goods in accordance with paragraph 2.1(a) and the mixture or solution is not identified by a shipping name in Schedule 1. However, if the classification for the dangerous goods does not precisely describe the mixture or solution but the mixture or solution meets the criteria in this Part for inclusion in at least one of the nine classes of dangerous goods, then sections 2.4 and 2.5 must be used to determine its classification.

Subsection.Text: A substance is a marine pollutant if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the letter “P” (marine pollutant) is set out in column 4 of Schedule 3 for the substance; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the substance meets the criteria for classification as a marine pollutant in accordance with section 2.9.3 or chapter 2.10 of the IMDG Code.

Subsection.Text: When dangerous goods meet the criteria for inclusion in more than one class but meet the criteria for inclusion in only one of the following classes, that one class is the primary class. The classes are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Class 1, Explosives, except for the following dangerous goods for which Class 1 is a subsidiary class:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3101, ORGANIC PEROXIDE TYPE B, LIQUID,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3102, ORGANIC PEROXIDE TYPE B, SOLID,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3111, ORGANIC PEROXIDE TYPE B, LIQUID, TEMPERATURE CONTROLLED,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3112, ORGANIC PEROXIDE TYPE B, SOLID, TEMPERATURE CONTROLLED,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3221, SELF-REACTIVE LIQUID TYPE B,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3222, SELF-REACTIVE SOLID TYPE B,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3231, SELF-REACTIVE LIQUID TYPE B, TEMPERATURE CONTROLLED, and

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3232, SELF-REACTIVE SOLID TYPE B, TEMPERATURE CONTROLLED;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Class 2, Gases, and within this class, Class 2.3, Toxic Gases, takes precedence over Class 2.1, Flammable Gases, and Class 2.1, Flammable Gases, takes precedence over Class 2.2, Non-flammable and Non-toxic Gases;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Class 4.1, Flammable Solids, desensitized explosives included in Packing Group I or self-reactive substances;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: Class 4.2, Substances Liable to Spontaneous Combustion, pyrophoric solids or liquids included in Packing Group I;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: Class 5.2, Organic Peroxides;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: Class 6.1, Toxic Substances, that are included in Packing Group I, due to inhalation toxicity;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: Class 6.2, Infectious Substances; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: Class 7, Radioactive Materials.

Subsection.Text: Despite paragraph (1)(f), Class 8 is the primary class when a substance meets the criteria for inclusion in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Class 8, Corrosives;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group I due to inhalation toxicity of dusts or mists; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group III due to oral or dermal toxicity.

Subsection.Text: A consignor must determine the order of precedence among classes that are not listed in subsection (1) in accordance with the following table, except that Class 6.1 takes precedence if a substance is a pesticide under the Pesticide Act and is included in Class 6.1, Packing Group III, and in Class 3, Packing Group III.

table.title: Precedence of Classes — Class and Packing Group

Provision.Text: X = any route of exposure - D, O or i

Section.Text: Substances are included in Class 1, Explosives, if they are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: capable, by chemical reaction, of producing gas at a temperature, pressure and speed that would damage the surroundings; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: designed to produce an explosive or pyrotechnic effect by heat, light, sound, gas or smoke or a combination of those means as a result of non-detonative, self-sustaining exothermic chemical reactions.

Section.Text: Class 1, Explosives, has six divisions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Class 1.1, mass explosion hazard;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Class 1.2, projection hazard but not a mass explosion hazard;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Class 1.3, fire hazard and either a minor blast hazard or a minor projection hazard or both but not a mass explosion hazard;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: Class 1.4, no significant hazard beyond the package in the event of ignition or initiation during transport;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: Class 1.5, very insensitive substances with a mass explosion hazard; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: Class 1.6, extremely insensitive articles with no mass explosion hazard.

Section.Text: Explosives are divided into 13 compatibility groups as described in Appendix 2, Description of Compatibility Groups, Class 1, Explosives, to this Part.
Explosives are included in Packing Group II.
A substance is included in Class 2, Gases, if it is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a gas included in one of the three divisions set out in section 2.14;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a mixture of gases;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a mixture of one or more gases with one or more vapours of substances included in other classes;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an article charged with a gas;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: tellurium hexafluoride; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: an aerosol.

Section.Text: Class 2, Gases, has three divisions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Class 2.1, Flammable Gases, which consists of gases that, at 20°C and an absolute pressure of 101.3 kPa,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are ignitable when in a mixture of 13% or less by volume with air, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: have a flammability range with air of at least 12 percentage points determined in accordance with tests or calculations in ISO 10156;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Class 2.2, Non-flammable and Non-toxic Gases, which consists of gases that are transported at an absolute pressure greater than or equal to 280 kPa at 20°C, or as refrigerated liquids, and that are not included in Class 2.1, Flammable Gases, or Class 2.3, Toxic Gases; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Class 2.3, Toxic Gases, which consists of gases that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are known to be toxic or corrosive to humans according to CGA P-20, ISO Standard 10298 or other documentary evidence published in technical journals or government publications, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: have an LC50 value less than or equal to 5 000 mL/m3.

Subsection.Text: Dangerous goods contained in an aerosol container must be transported under UN1950, AEROSOLS.
The dangerous goods are included

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in Class 2.1, Flammable Gases, if the dangerous goods contain at least 85% by mass of flammable components and the chemical heat of combustion is greater than or equal to 30 kJ/g; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in Class 2.2, Non-flammable and Non-toxic Gases, if the dangerous goods contain not more than 1% by mass of flammable components and the heat of combustion is less than 20 kJ/g.

Subsection.Text: The dangerous goods must be classified in accordance with section 31 of Part III of the Manual of Tests and Criteria.
The dangerous goods must not contain gases included in Class 2.3, Toxic Gases.

The dangerous goods must have a subsidiary class of 6.1, Toxic Substances, or Class 8, Corrosive Substances, if the dangerous goods – other than the propellant to be ejected from the aerosol container – are included in Class 6.1, Toxic Substances, Packing Groups II or III, or Class 8, Corrosive Substances, Packing Groups II or III.
The dangerous goods are forbidden for transport when they are included in Packing Group I for toxicity or corrosiveness.

These Regulations, except for Part 1 (Coming into Force, Repeal, Interpretation, General Provisions and Special Cases) and Part 2 (Classification) do not apply to gases included in Class 2.2, Non-flammable and Non-toxic Gases that are contained

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in foodstuffs, including carbonated beverages other than UN1950;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in balls intended for use in sports;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in tires; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in light bulbs.

Subsection.Text: The exemption set out in paragraph (1)(d) applies only if the light bulbs are packaged so that any pieces of a ruptured bulb are contained by the packaging.

Section.Text: There are no packing groups for Class 2, Gases.
LC50 values for a single or pure gas or for a mixture of gases must be determined

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by using LC50 values published in CGA P-20, ISO Standard 10298, technical journals or government publications;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with paragraphs 2.2.3(b) and (c) of Chapter 2.2 of the UN Recommendations; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for a mixture of gases, in accordance with section 2.17.

Heading.TitleText: Determination of LC50 of a Mixture of Gases

Section.Text: To determine the LC50 of a mixture of gases when the LC50 of each of the gases is known, use 5 000 mL/m3 as the toxic limit and,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the mixture contains only one gas with an LC50 less than or equal to the toxic limit (called “Gas A”), use the following calculation:

Provision.Text: LC50 of the mixture = LC50 of Gas Afraction by volume of Gas A in the mixture

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the mixture contains more than one gas with an LC50 less than or equal to the toxic limit (called “Gas A”, “Gas B”, etc.),

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: determine the contributing number (CN) of each of the gases with an LC50 less than or equal to the toxic limit using the formula

Formula.FormulaText: CN Gas A = LC50 of Gas Afraction by volume of Gas A in the mixture

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: combine the contributing numbers (CN) of each gas with an LC50 less than or equal to the toxic limit using the formula

Formula.FormulaText: T = 1CN Gas A + 1CN Gas B + (as needed)

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: obtain the LC50 of the mixture by dividing 1 by the number T (LC50 of the mixture = 1 / T).

Subsection.Text: Substances that are liquids or liquids containing solids in solution or suspension are included in Class 3, Flammable Liquids, if they

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have a flash point less than or equal to 60ºC using the closed-cup test method referred to in Chapter 2.3 of the UN Recommendations; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are intended or expected to be at a temperature that is greater than or equal to their flash point at any time while the substances are in transport.

Subsection.Text: Despite paragraph (1)(a), liquids that have a flash point greater than 35°C are not included in Class 3, Flammable Liquids, if they

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: do not sustain combustion, as determined in accordance with the sustained combustibility test referred to in section 2.3.1.3 of Chapter 2.3 of the UN Recommendations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have a fire point greater than 100°C, as determined in accordance with ISO 2592; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: are water-miscible solutions with a water content greater than 90% by mass.

Subsection.Text: Flammable liquids included in Class 3, Flammable Liquids, are included in one of the following packing groups:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group I, if they have an initial boiling point of 35°C or less at an absolute pressure of 101.3 kPa and any flash point;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group II, if they have an initial boiling point greater than 35°C at an absolute pressure of 101.3 kPa and a flash point less than 23°C; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group III, if the criteria for inclusion in Packing Group I or II are not met.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (1), for dangerous goods included in Class 3, Flammable Liquids,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when the packing group is unknown, the consignor may include the dangerous goods in Packing Group I; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when the packing group is reasonably believed or is known to be Packing Group II or III, the consignor may include the dangerous goods in Packing Group II but, if the substance has the same characteristics as UN1203, GASOLINE, it may also be transported as Packing Group II.

Subsection.Text: Despite paragraph (1)(b), a viscous flammable liquid that has a flash point less than 23°C may be included in Packing Group III if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the liquid or any separated solvent does not meet the criteria for inclusion in Class 6.1 or Class 8;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: less than 3% of the clear solvent layer separates when the solvent separation test set out in subsection 32.5.1 of Part III of the Manual of Tests and Criteria is carried out;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the viscosity and flash-point of the liquid are in accordance with the table to this subsection; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the viscosity test is carried out in accordance with the procedure set out in subsection 32.4 of Part III of the Manual of Tests and Criteria or the procedure set out in ISO 2431.

row.entry: Kinematic viscosity extrapolated ν (at near-zero shear rate) mm2/s at 23°C

Subsection.Text: If a liquid referred to in subsection (3) is a non-Newtonian substance or a flow cup method of viscosity determination is unsuitable, a variable shear-rate viscometer must be used to determine the dynamic viscosity coefficient of the liquid, at 23°C, at a number of shear rates. The values obtained must be plotted against shear rate and then extrapolated to zero shear rate. The dynamic viscosity value thus obtained, divided by the density, gives the apparent kinematic viscosity at near-zero shear rate.

Heading.TitleText: Class 4, Flammable Solids; Substances Liable to Spontaneous Combustion; Substances That on Contact with Water Emit Flammable Gases (Water-reactive Substances)

Section.Text: Substances are included in Class 4 if they are flammable solids, substances liable to spontaneous combustion or substances that on contact with water emit flammable gases (water-reactive substances) and meet the criteria for inclusion in one of the divisions and packing groups of Class 4.

Subsection.Text: Class 4 has three divisions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Class 4.1, Flammable Solids, which consists of substances that are

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: readily combustible, as determined in accordance with section 2.4.2.2 of Chapter 2.4 of the UN Recommendations,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: under normal conditions of transport, liable to cause fire through friction,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: solid desensitized explosives, which are solid explosives desensitized through wetting with water or alcohols or diluted with other substances to form a homogeneous solid mixture to suppress their explosive properties so that they are not included in Class 1, Explosives,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: self-reactive substances that are liable to undergo a strongly exothermic decomposition even without the participation of oxygen (air), as determined in accordance with section 2.4.2.3 of Chapter 2.4 of the UN Recommendations, but Class 4.1 does not include substances that have

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: a primary class of Class 1, Explosives, Class 5.1, Oxidizing Substances, or Class 5.2, Organic Peroxides,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: a heat of decomposition less than 300 J/g, or

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: a self-accelerating decomposition temperature (SADT) that is greater than 75°C for a 50 kg means of containment, as determined in accordance with section 2.4.2.3.4 of Chapter 2.4 of the UN Recommendations,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv.1)
Subparagraph.Text: polymerizing substances that, without stabilization, are liable to undergo a strongly exothermic reaction resulting in the formation of larger molecules or resulting in the formation of polymers under conditions normally encountered in transport,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: identified by one of the following UN numbers: UN2956, UN3241, UN3242 or UN3251, or

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: are in the list of currently assigned self-reactive substances in section 2.4.2.3.2.3 of Chapter 2.4 of the UN Recommendations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Class 4.2, Substances Liable to Spontaneous Combustion, which consists of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: pyrophoric substances that spontaneously ignite within 5 minutes after coming into contact with air, as determined in accordance with section 2.4.3.2 of Chapter 2.4 of the UN Recommendations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: self-heating substances that, when in large amounts (kilograms), spontaneously ignite on contact with air after long periods (hours or days), as determined in accordance with section 2.4.3.2 of Chapter 2.4 of the UN Recommendations; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Class 4.3, Water-reactive Substances, which consists of substances that, in tests performed in accordance with section 2.4.4.2 of Chapter 2.4 of the UN Recommendations, emit a flammable gas at a rate greater than 1 L/kg of substance per hour or spontaneously ignite at any step in the test procedure.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subparagraph (1)(a)(iv.1), a substance is considered to be a polymerizing substance of Class 4.1 if it

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: has a self-accelerating polymerization temperature (SAPT) that is less than or equal to 75°C under the conditions in which the substance or mixture is to be transported, with or without chemical stabilization as offered for transport, and in the means of containment in which the substance or mixture is to be transported;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: exhibits a heat of reaction of more than 300 J/g; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: does not meet any other criteria for inclusion in Classes 1 to 8.

Section.Text: A person must not offer for transport, handle or transport the following polymerizing substances unless they are stabilized by temperature control:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: polymerizing substance that is in a small means of containment prescribed by TP 14850 or Chapter 6.1 of the UN Recommendations or in an intermediate bulk container (IBC) and whose self-accelerating polymerization temperature (SAPT) is 50°C or less in the small means of containment or IBC; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a polymerizing substance that is in a large means of containment that is not an IBC and whose SAPT is 45°C or less in the large means of containment.

Subsection.Text: Substances included in Class 4.1, Flammable Solids, are included in one of the following packing groups:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group I, if the substances meet the criterion in subparagraph 2.21(1)(a)(iii), except that substances that have one of the following UN numbers are included in Packing Group II: UN2555, UN2556, UN2557, UN2907, UN3270, UN3319 or UN3344;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group II, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the substances meet the criteria for inclusion in Class 4.1 in subparagraph 2.21(1)(a)(iv) or (v), except that substances that have one of the following UN numbers are included in Packing Group III: UN2956, UN3241 or UN3251,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in tests referred to in section 33.2.1 of Part III of the Manual of Tests and Criteria for readily combustible solids, excluding metal powders, the burning time of the substances is less than 45 seconds and the flame passes the wetted zone, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in tests referred to in section 33.2.1 of Part III of the Manual of Tests and Criteria, for readily combustible solids that are powders of metals or metal alloys, the zone of reaction of the substances spreads over the whole length of the sample in 5 minutes or less; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group III, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in tests referred to in section 33.2.1 of Part III of the Manual of Tests and Criteria, for readily combustible solids, excluding metal powders, the burning time of the substances is less than 45 seconds and the wetted zone stops the flame propagation for at least 4 minutes,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in tests referred to in section 33.2.1 of Part III of the Manual of Tests and Criteria, for readily combustible solids that are powders of metals or metal alloys, the zone of reaction of the substances spreads over the whole length of the sample in more than 5 minutes but not more than 10 minutes, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the substances are solids that are liable to cause fire through friction.

Subsection.Text: Substances included in Class 4.2, Substances Liable to Spontaneous Combustion, are included in one of the following packing groups:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group I, if the substances are pyrophoric solids or liquids;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group II, if the substances are self-heating substances that give a positive result, as determined in accordance with section 2.4.3.2 of Chapter 2.4 of the UN Recommendations using a 25 mm sample cube at 140°C; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group III for all other substances.

Subsection.Text: Substances included in Class 4.3, Water-reactive Substances, are included in one of the following packing groups:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group I, if the substances

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: react vigorously with water at ambient temperatures and demonstrate a tendency for the gas produced to ignite spontaneously, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: react readily with water at ambient temperatures so that the rate of evolution of flammable gas is greater than or equal to 10 L/kg of substance over any one minute;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group II, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the substances react readily with water at ambient temperatures so that the rate of evolution of flammable gas is greater than or equal to 20 L/kg of substance per hour, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the criteria for inclusion in Packing Group I are not met; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group III, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the substances react slowly with water at ambient temperatures so that the rate of evolution of flammable gas is greater than or equal to 1 L/kg of substance per hour, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the criteria for inclusion in Packing Group I or II are not met.

Heading.TitleText: Class 5, Oxidizing Substances and Organic Peroxides

Section.Text: Substances are included in Class 5 if they are oxidizing substances or organic peroxides and meet the criteria for inclusion in one of the divisions of Class 5.
Class 5 has two divisions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Class 5.1, Oxidizing Substances, which consists of substances that yield oxygen thereby causing or contributing to the combustion of other material, as determined in accordance with section 2.5.2 of Chapter 2.5 of the UN Recommendations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Class 5.2, Organic Peroxides, which consists of substances that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are thermally unstable organic compounds that contain oxygen in the bivalent “-O-O-” structure, as determined in accordance with section 2.5.3 of Chapter 2.5 of the UN Recommendations,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: are liable to undergo exothermic self-accelerating decomposition,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: have one or more of the following characteristics:

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: they are liable to explosive decomposition,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: they burn rapidly,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: they are sensitive to impact or friction,

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: they react dangerously with other substances, or

Clause.Label: (E)
Clause.Text: they cause damage to the eyes, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: are in the list of currently assigned organic peroxides in section 2.5.3.2.4 of Chapter 2.5 of the UN Recommendations.

Subsection.Text: The packing group for a substance that is included in Class 5.1, Oxidizing Substances, must be determined by using a test sample of the substance that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a solid, is prepared in accordance with section 2.5.2.2 of Chapter 2.5 of the UN Recommendations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a liquid, is prepared in accordance with section 2.5.2.3 of Chapter 2.5 of the UN Recommendations.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a solid substance included in Class 5.1, Oxidizing Substances, the test procedure set out in either subsection 34.4.1 (test O.1) or subsection 34.4.3 (test O.3) of Part III of the Manual of Tests and Criteria must be carried out on the test sample. The substance is included in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group I, if the test sample exhibits an average burning time that is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: less than the mean burning time of a 3:2 potassium bromate/cellulose mixture by mass when test O.1 is used, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: greater than the mean burning rate of a 3:1 calcium peroxide/cellulose mixture by mass when test O.3 is used;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group II, if the criteria for Packing Group I are not met and the test sample exhibits an average burning time that is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: less than or equal to the mean burning time of a 2:3 potassium bromate/cellulose mixture by mass, when test O.1 is used, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: equal to or greater than the mean burning rate of a 1:1 calcium peroxide/cellulose mixture by mass, when test O.3 is used; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group III, if the criteria for Packing Groups I and II are not met and the test sample exhibits an average burning time that is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: less than or equal to the mean burning time of a 3:7 potassium bromate/cellulose mixture by mass, when test O.1 is used, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: equal to or greater than the mean burning rate of a 1:2 calcium peroxide/cellulose mixture by mass, when test O.3 is used.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a liquid substance included in Class 5.1, Oxidizing Substances, the test procedure set out in sub-section 34.4.2 (test O.2) of Part III of the Manual of Tests and Criteria must be carried out on the test sample. The substance is included in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group I, if the test sample in a 1:1 mixture by mass of substance and cellulose spontaneously ignites or the mean pressure rise time is less than that of a 1:1 mixture by mass of 50% perchloric acid and cellulose;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group II, if the mean pressure rise time is less than or equal to the mean pressure rise time of a 1:1 mixture by mass of 40% aqueous sodium chlorate solution and cellulose and the criteria for inclusion in Packing Group I are not met; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group III, if the mean pressure rise time is less than or equal to the mean pressure rise time of a 1:1 mixture by mass of 65% aqueous nitric acid solution and cellulose and the criteria for inclusion in Packing Group I or II are not met.

Subsection.Text: Class 5.2, Organic Peroxides, are included in Packing Group II.
The type, B to F, of organic peroxides must be determined in accordance with section 2.5.3.3 of Chapter 2.5 of the UN Recommendations.

Section.Text: Substances are included in Class 6 if they are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: liable to cause death or serious injury or to harm human health if swallowed or inhaled or if they come into contact with human skin; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: infectious substances.

Section.Text: Class 6 has two divisions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Class 6.1, Toxic Substances, which consists of substances that are liable to cause death or serious injury or to harm human health if swallowed or inhaled or if they come into contact with human skin; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Class 6.2, Infectious Substances, which consists of infectious substances.

Heading.TitleText: Criteria for Inclusion in Class 6.1, Toxic Substances

Section.Text: A substance is included in Class 6.1

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: due to oral toxicity if its LD50 (oral) is less than or equal to 300 mg/kg;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: due to dermal toxicity if its LD50 (dermal) is less than or equal to 1 000 mg/kg; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: due to inhalation toxicity

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: by dust or mist if dust or mist is likely to be produced in a transport accident and its LC50 (inhalation) is less than or equal to 4 mg/L, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: by vapour if its LC50 (inhalation) is less than or equal to 5 000 mL/m3.

Subsection.Text: When a substance is known to be included in Class 6.1 and that knowledge is based on documentary evidence published in technical journals or government publications and testing is not done to determine the packing group, the substance must be included in Packing Group I.
Substances that are included in Class 6.1 due to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: oral toxicity are included in one of the following packing groups:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: Packing Group I, if the LD50 (oral) is less than or equal to 5 mg/kg,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: Packing Group II, if the LD50 (oral) is greater than 5 mg/kg but less than or equal to 50 mg/kg, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: Packing Group III, if the LD50 (oral) is greater than 50 mg/kg but less than or equal to 300 mg/kg;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: dermal toxicity are included in one of the following packing groups:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: Packing Group I if the LD50 (dermal) is less than or equal to 50 mg/kg,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: Packing Group II if the LD50 (dermal) is greater than 50 mg/kg but less than or equal to 200 mg/kg, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: Packing Group III if the LD50 (dermal) is greater than 200 mg/kg but less than or equal to 1 000 mg/kg;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: inhalation toxicity by dust or mist are included in one of the following packing groups:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: Packing Group I if the LC50 (inhalation) is less than or equal to 0.2 mg/L,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: Packing Group II if the LC50 (inhalation) is greater than 0.2 mg/L but less than or equal to 2 mg/L, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: Packing Group III if the LC50 (inhalation) is greater than 2 mg/L but less than or equal to 4 mg/L; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: inhalation toxicity by vapour are included in one of the following packing groups, where “V” is the saturated vapour concentration in millilitres per cubic metre of air at 20°C and at 101.3 kPa:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: Packing Group I, if

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: V is greater than or equal to 10 multiplied by the LC50, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the LC50 is less than or equal to 1 000 mL/m3,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: Packing Group II, if

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: V is greater than or equal to the LC50,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the LC50 is less than or equal to 3 000 mL/m3, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: the criteria for Packing Group I are not met, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: Packing Group III, if

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: V is greater than or equal to 0.2 multiplied by the LC50,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the LC50 is less than or equal to 5 000 mL/m3, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: the criteria for inclusion in Packing Group I or II are not met.

Section.Text: LD50 (oral or dermal) values for solid or liquid substances or for a mixture of solid or liquid substances must be determined

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by using the LD50 values published in technical journals or in government publications;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with section 2.6.2.3 of Chapter 2.6 of the UN Recommendations; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for a mixture of solid or liquid substances, in accordance with section 2.31.

Heading.TitleText: Determination of LD50 (oral or dermal) of a Mixture of Substances

Section.Text: To determine the LD50 of a mixture of solid or liquid substances when the LD50 of each of the substances is known, use 1 000 mg/kg as the toxic limit and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the mixture contains only one substance with an LD50 less than or equal to the toxic limit (called “Substance A”), use the following calculation:

Provision.Text: LD50 of the mixture = LD50 of Substance Afraction by mass of Substance A in the mixture

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the mixture contains more than one substance with an LD50 less than or equal to the toxic limit (called “Substance A”, “Substance B”, etc.),

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: determine the lowest LD50 of all substances, assign that LD50 to all substances whose actual LD50 is less than or equal to the toxic limit, then use the calculation in paragraph (a) using that assigned LD50 and taking as the mass of Substance A in the formula the total of the masses of all substances whose actual LD50 is less than or equal to the toxic limit, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: use the following calculations:

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: determine the contributing number (CN) of each of the substances with an LD50 less than or equal to the toxic limit using the formula

Provision.Text: CN for Substance A= LD50 of Substance Afraction by mass of Substance A in the mixture

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: combine the contributing numbers (CN) of each substance with an LD50 less than or equal to the toxic limit as

Formula.FormulaText: T = 1CN Substance A + 1CN Substance B + (as needed)

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: obtain the LD50 of the mixture by dividing 1 by the number T (LD50 of the mixture = 1 / T).

Heading.TitleText: Determination of LC50 (dust, mist or vapour)

Section.Text: LC50 values for a substance in the form of a dust, mist or vapour or for a mixture of substances in the form of a dust, mist or vapour must be determined

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by using the LC50 values published in technical journals or in government publications;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with sections 2.6.2.2.4.2 to 2.6.2.2.4.7 of Chapter 2.6 of the UN Recommendations; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for a mixture of substances, in accordance with section 2.33.

Heading.TitleText: Determination of LC50 (dust, mist or vapour) of a Mixture of Substances

Section.Text: To determine the LC50 of a mixture of substances that are in the form of a dust, mist or vapour, when the LC50 of each of the substances is known, make the determination in accordance with section 2.17, except that for a dust use 10 mg/L as the toxic limit and for a mist use 2 mg/L as the toxic limit. For a substance in the form of vapour the toxic limit is the same as for a gas, which is 5 000 mL/m3.

Heading.TitleText: Determination of the Packing Group of a Mixture of Liquids with an Inhalation Toxicity by Vapour

Subsection.Text: The first step in determining the packing group of a mixture of liquids with an inhalation toxicity by vapour when one or more of the substances has an LC50 (vapour) less than or equal to 5 000 mL/m3, and the LC50 of each substance is known, is to determine the following data:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: determine the LC50 (vapour) for the mixture in accordance with section 2.33;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where Pi is the vapour pressure of the ith substance in kPa at 20°C and an absolute pressure of 101.3 kPa, determine the volatility, Vi, of each substance in the mixture as

Provision.Text: Vi = Pi multiplied by 106 then divided by 101.3;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: determine the ratio of the volatility of a substance to its LC50 for each substance with an LC50 less than or equal to 5 000 mL/m3 as

Provision.Text: Ri = Vi divided by the LC50 of the ith substance;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: set R equal to the sum of the Ri for each of the substances with an LC50 less than or equal to 5 000 mL/m3 as

Subsection.Text: Using the data determined in accordance with subsection (1), the mixture is included in one of the following packing groups:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group I, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: R is greater than or equal to 10, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the LC50 (mixture) is less than or equal to 1 000 mL/m3;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group II, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: R is greater than or equal to 1,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the LC50 (mixture) is less than or equal to 3 000 mL/m3, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the criteria for inclusion in Packing Group I are not met; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group III, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: R is greater than or equal to 0.2,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the LC50 (mixture) is less than or equal to 5 000 mL/m3, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the criteria for inclusion in Packing Group I or II are not met.

Heading.TitleText: Determination of the Packing Group of a Mixture of Liquids with an Inhalation Toxicity and an Unknown LC50

Subsection.Text: A mixture of liquids with an inhalation toxicity and an unknown LC50 is included in Packing Group I if it meets the following criteria:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when a sample of the mixture is vapourized and diluted with air to create a test atmosphere of 1 000 mL/m3 and 10 young adult albino rats (5 male and 5 female) are exposed to the test atmosphere for 1 hour and observed for 14 days, the result is the death of 5 or more of the animals within the 14-day observation period; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when a sample of the vapour in equilibrium with the mixture at 20°C is diluted with 9 equal volumes of air to form a test atmosphere and 10 young adult albino rats (5 male and 5 female) are exposed to the test atmosphere for 1 hour and observed for 14 days, the result is the death of 5 or more of the animals within the 14-day observation period.

Subsection.Text: A mixture of liquids with an inhalation toxicity and an unknown LC50 is included in Packing Group II if it meets the following criteria and the criteria for inclusion in Packing Group I are not met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when a sample of the mixture is vapourized and diluted with air to create a test atmosphere of 3 000 mL/m3 and 10 young adult albino rats (5 male and 5 female) are exposed to the test atmosphere for 1 hour and observed for 14 days, the result is the death of 5 or more of the animals within the 14-day observation period; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when a sample of the vapour in equilibrium with the mixture at 20°C is used to form a test atmosphere and 10 young adult albino rats (5 male and 5 female) are exposed to the test atmosphere for 1 hour and observed for 14 days, the result is the death of 5 or more of the animals within the 14-day observation period.

Subsection.Text: A mixture of liquids with an inhalation toxicity and an unknown LC50 is included in Packing Group III if it meets the following criteria and the criteria for inclusion in Packing Group I or II are not met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when a sample of the mixture is vapourized and diluted with air to create a test atmosphere of 5 000 mL/m3 and 10 young adult albino rats (5 male and 5 female) are exposed to the test atmosphere for 1 hour and observed for 14 days, the result is the death of 5 or more of the animals within the 14-day observation period; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when the vapour pressure of the mixture is measured, the vapour concentration is greater than or equal to 1 000 mL/m3.

Subsection.Text: If only LC50 data relating to 4-hour exposures to dust or mist are available, those figures can be multiplied by 4 and the result taken as the LC50 data for 1 hour, that is LC50 4 hours (dust or mist) multiplied by 4 is equivalent to LC50 1 hour.

If only LC50 data relating to 4-hour exposures to vapour are available, those figures can be multiplied by 2 and the result taken as the LC50 data for 1 hour, that is LC50 4 hours (vapour) multiplied by 2 is equivalent to LC50 1 hour.

Substances are included in Class 6.2, Category A or Category B if they are infectious substances and are listed in Appendix 3 to this Part or exhibit characteristics similar to a substance listed in that appendix.

Infectious substances that are included in Category A and that are in a form other than a culture may be handled, offered for transport or transported as Category B in accordance with the conditions set out in paragraphs 1.39(a) to (c) of Part 1 (Coming into Force, Repeal, Interpretation, General Provisions and Special Cases).

Despite subsection (2), the following infectious substances included in Category A, and any substance that exhibits characteristics similar to these substances, must always be handled, offered for transport or transported as Category A:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic fever virus;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Ebola virus;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Flexal virus;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: Guanarito virus;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: Hantaviruses causing hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: Hantaviruses causing pulmonary syndrome;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: Hendra virus;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: Herpes B virus (Cercopithecine Herpesvirus-1);

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: Junin virus;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: Kyasanur Forest virus;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: Lassa virus;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: Machupo virus;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: Marburg virus;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: Monkeypox virus;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: Nipah virus;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: Omsk hemorrhagic fever virus;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: Russian Spring – Summer encephalitis virus;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: Sabia virus; and

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: Variola (smallpox virus).

Section.Text: Dangerous goods that are medical or clinical waste must be classified

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: under UN2814 or, as applicable, under UN2900, if they contain Category A infectious substances;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: under UN3291, if they contain Category B infectious substances; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: under UN3291, if the shipper has reasonable grounds to believe that they have a low probability of containing infectious substances.

Section.Text: Substances defined as Class 7, Radioactive Materials in the Packaging and Transport of Nuclear Substances Regulations are included in Class 7, Radioactive Materials.
There are no divisions for Class 7.
There are no packing groups for Class 7.
Substances are included in Class 8, Corrosives, if they

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are known to cause full thickness destruction of human skin, that is, skin lesions that are permanent and destroy all layers of the outer skin through to the internal tissues;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: cause full thickness skin destruction, as determined in accordance with OECD Guideline 430 or OECD Guideline 431; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: do not cause full thickness destruction of skin, but exhibit a corrosion rate that exceeds 6.25 mm per year at a test temperature of 55°C, as determined in accordance with section 37 of Part III of the Manual of Tests and Criteria.

Section.Text: There are no divisions for Class 8.

Subsection.Text: If a substance is known to be included in Class 8, Corrosives, and that knowledge is based on documentary evidence published in technical journals or government publications and testing is not done to determine the packing group, the substance must be included in Packing Group I.
Class 8, Corrosives, are included in one of the following packing groups:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Group I, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: they are known to cause full thickness destruction of human skin, that is, skin lesions that are permanent and that destroy all layers of the outer skin through to the internal tissues, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: full thickness destruction of intact skin tissue occurs within an observation period of 60 minutes after an exposure time of 3 minutes or less, as determined in accordance with OECD Guideline 404 or OECD Guideline 435;
