In addition to the requirements set out in subsection (1), a person who uses a means of containment that is required under CGSB-43.146 for the offering for transport of dangerous goods must follow the requirements of clauses 12.2, 12.3 and 12.4 of CGSB-43.146.

A person must not handle, offer for transport or transport dangerous goods included in Class 3, 4, 5, 6.1, 8 or 9 in a large means of containment unless it is manufactured, selected and used in accordance with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for transport by road vehicle,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the requirements of Part II of CGSB-43.146, if the means of containment is a UN standardized means of containment,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: CSA B621, except clause 8.2(b), and, despite any indication to the contrary in CSA B620, Annex B of CSA B620,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: CSA B625, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: TP 14877, if the means of containment is a ton container;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for transport by railway vehicle,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the requirements of Part II of CGSB-43.146, if the means of containment is a UN standardized means of containment,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: TP 14877, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: CSA B625;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for transport by aircraft, Part 12 (Air) of these Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: for transport by vessel,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the requirements of Part II of CGSB-43.146, if the means of containment is a UN standardized means of containment,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: CSA B621, except clause 8.2(b), and, despite any indication to the contrary in CSA B620, Annex B of CSA B620, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: CSA B625.

Subsection.Text: In addition to the requirements of subparagraphs (1)(a)(ii) and (d)(iii), a person who uses a standardized means of containment that is required by CSA B621 to offer for transport dangerous goods included in Class 3, 4, 5, 6.1, 8 or 9 must use a means of containment

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: manufactured in accordance with CSA B620 if the means of containment was manufactured in Canada on or after August 31, 2008; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: tested and inspected in accordance with CSA B620 when the most recent periodic re-test or periodic inspection is performed in Canada on or after August 31, 2008.

Heading.TitleText: Means of Containment for Class 6.2, Infectious Substances

Subsection.Text: A person must not offer for transport, handle or transport dangerous goods included in Category A or Category B of Class 6.2, Infectious Substances, unless the dangerous goods are in a means of containment that is manufactured, selected and used in accordance with CGSB-43.125.

If the means of containment is made available as a kit, the packaging manufacturer and subsequent distributor must provide the packaging information required under section 4.4 of CGSB-43.125 to the packaging purchaser at each initial purchase and to a packaging user upon request.

Heading.TitleText: Means of Containment for Class 7, Radioactive Materials

Section.Text: A person must not offer for transport, handle or transport dangerous goods included in Class 7 in a means of containment unless the means of containment is in compliance with the Packaging and Transport of Nuclear Substances Regulations, 2015.
A person must not use a consolidation bin to handle or transport dangerous goods in a road vehicle unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the capacity of the consolidation bin is less than or equal to 1.8 m3 (64 cubic feet);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the consolidation bin is reusable and constructed of plastic, wood or metal; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the consolidation bin is blocked or braced within the road vehicle.

Subsection.Text: A person who handles, offers for transport or transports dangerous goods must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be adequately trained and hold a training certificate in accordance with this Part; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: perform those activities in the presence and under the direct supervision of a person who is adequately trained and who holds a training certificate in accordance with this Part.

Subsection.Text: An employer must not direct or allow an employee to handle, offer for transport or transport dangerous goods unless the employee

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is adequately trained and holds a training certificate in accordance with this Part; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: performs those activities in the presence and under the direct supervision of a person who is adequately trained and who holds a training certificate in accordance with this Part.

Section.Text: A person is adequately trained if the person has a sound knowledge of all the topics listed in paragraphs (a) to (m) that relate directly to the person’s duties and to the dangerous goods the person is expected to handle, offer for transport or transport:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the classification criteria and test methods in Part 2 (Classification);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shipping names;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the use of Schedules 1, 2 and 3;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the shipping document and train consist requirements in Part 3 (Documentation);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the dangerous goods safety marks requirements in Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the certification safety marks requirements, safety requirements and safety standards in Part 5 (Means of Containment);

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the ERAP requirements in Part 7 (Emergency Response Assistance Plan);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the report requirements in Part 8 (Reporting Requirements);

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: safe handling and transportation practices for dangerous goods, including the characteristics of the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the proper use of any equipment used to handle or transport the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the reasonable emergency measures the person must take to reduce or eliminate any danger to public safety that results or may reasonably be expected to result from an accidental release of the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: for air transport, the aspects of training set out in Chapter 4, Training, of Part 1, General, of the ICAO Technical Instructions for the persons named in that Chapter and the requirements in Part 12 (Air) of these Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: for marine transport, the requirements of the IMDG Code and the requirements of Part 11 (Marine) of these Regulations.

Heading.TitleText: Issuance and Contents of a Training Certificate

Subsection.Text: An employer who has reasonable grounds to believe that an employee is adequately trained and will perform duties to which the training relates must issue a training certificate to the employee that includes the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the place of business of the employer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the employee’s name;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date the training certificate expires, preceded by the words “Expires on” or “Date d’expiration”; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the aspects of handling, offering for transport or transporting dangerous goods for which the employee is trained, including the specific topics set out in section 6.2.

Subsection.Text: A self-employed person who has reasonable grounds to believe that he or she is adequately trained and who will perform duties to which the training relates must issue to himself or herself a training certificate that includes the information required by subsection (1).
The training certificate must be signed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by the employee and by the employer or another employee acting on behalf of the employer; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a self-employed person, by that person.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (1), if the employer of a person who is a member of a vessel’s complement has reasonable grounds to believe that the person’s certificate of competency issued in accordance with the Marine Certification Regulations is acceptable evidence that the person is adequately trained, the employer is not required to issue the training certificate. The certificate of competency is a valid training certificate for the purposes of these Regulations when the certificate of competency is valid in Canada.

A document that is issued to a driver of a road vehicle licensed in the United States or to a member of the crew of a train subject to 49 CFR for the transportation of dangerous goods and that indicates that the driver or the crew member is trained in accordance with sections 172.700 to 172.704 of 49 CFR is a valid training certificate for the purposes of these Regulations when that document is valid in the United States.

A document that is issued to a foreign member of the flight crew of an aircraft registered in a country that is a Member State of the International Civil Aviation Organization and that indicates that the crew member is trained to transport dangerous goods by air is a valid training certificate for the purposes of these Regulations, in accordance with Article 33 of the Convention on International Civil Aviation, when that document is valid in the Member State.

A document that is issued to a foreign member of the crew of a vessel registered in a country that is a Member State of the International Maritime Organization and that indicates that the crew member is trained to transport dangerous goods by vessel is a valid training certificate for the purposes of these Regulations when that document is valid in the Member State.

Section.Text: A training certificate expires

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for transport by aircraft, 24 months after its date of issuance; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for transport by road vehicle, railway vehicle or vessel, 36 months after its date of issuance.

Heading.TitleText: Keeping Proof of Training: Employer’s and Self-Employed Person’s Responsibility

Section.Text: An employer or a self-employed person must keep a record of training or a statement of experience, as well as a copy of a training certificate, in electronic or paper form, beginning on the date the training certificate is issued and continuing until two years after the date it expires.

Heading.TitleText: Showing Proof of Training: Employer’s and Self-Employed Person’s Responsibility

Section.Text: Within 15 days after the date of a written request by an inspector, the employer of a person who holds a training certificate or a self-employed person must provide a copy of the training certificate to the inspector and, if applicable, a copy of the record of training or the statement of experience and a description of the training material used in the person’s training.

Heading.TitleText: Showing Proof of Training: Trained Person’s Responsibility

Section.Text: A person who handles, offers for transport or transports dangerous goods, or who directly supervises another person engaged in these activities, must give his or her training certificate, or a copy of it, to an inspector immediately on request.
This Part sets out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the requirement to have an approved ERAP;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the approval of an ERAP;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the authorization to use an approved ERAP;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the implementation of an approved ERAP; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the compensation for the authorized implementation of an approved ERAP.

Heading.TitleText: Requirement to Have an Approved ERAP

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection 7(1) of the Act, an approved ERAP is required for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: dangerous goods that have the same UN number and that are contained in a single means of containment, if the quantity of those dangerous goods exceeds the ERAP index in column 7 of Schedule 1;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: dangerous goods, in a road vehicle or a railway vehicle, that have the same UN number and that are contained in more than one means of containment, if the total quantity of those dangerous goods exceeds the ERAP index in column 7 of Schedule 1 and are included in one of the following classes:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: Class 3, Flammable Liquids, with a subsidiary class of Class 6.1, Toxic Substances,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: Class 4, Flammable Solids; Substances Liable to Spontaneous Combustion; Substances That on Contact with Water Emit Flammable Gases (Water-reactive substances),

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: Class 5.2, Organic Peroxides, that are Type B or Type C,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: Class 6.1, Toxic Substances, that are included in Packing Group I;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: dangerous goods, in a road vehicle or a railway vehicle, that have the same UN number, and that are contained in more than one large means of containment, if the total quantity of those dangerous goods exceeds the ERAP index in column 7 of Schedule 1;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: dangerous goods, in a road vehicle or a railway vehicle, that are included in Class 1, Explosives, and that are contained in one or more means of containment, if the total quantity of those dangerous goods exceeds the ERAP index in column 7 of Schedule 1 for the explosives with the lowest index number in that column;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: dangerous goods that are included in Class 2, Gases, that have the same UN number, that are contained in more than one means of containment — each of which has a capacity greater than 225 L — that are a single unit as a result of being interconnected through a piping arrangement and that are permanently mounted on a structural frame for transport, if the total quantity of those dangerous goods exceeds the ERAP index in column 7 of Schedule 1;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any of the following dangerous goods that are transported by rail in a tank car, if the quantity of those dangerous goods in the tank car exceeds 10 000 L:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1170, ETHANOL with more than 24% ethanol, by volume, ETHANOL SOLUTION with more than 24% ethanol, by volume, ETHYL ALCOHOL with more than 24% ethanol, by volume, or ETHYL ALCOHOL SOLUTION with more than 24% ethanol, by volume,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1202, DIESEL FUEL, GAS OIL, or HEATING OIL, LIGHT,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1203, GASOLINE, MOTOR SPIRIT, or PETROL,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1267, PETROLEUM CRUDE OIL,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1268, PETROLEUM DISTILLATES, N.O.S., or PETROLEUM PRODUCTS, N.O.S.,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1863, FUEL, AVIATION, TURBINE ENGINE,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1987, ALCOHOLS, N.O.S.,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1993, FLAMMABLE LIQUID, N.O.S.,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3295, HYDROCARBONS, LIQUID, N.O.S.,

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3475, ETHANOL AND GASOLINE MIXTURE, with more than 10% ethanol, ETHANOL AND MOTOR SPIRIT MIXTURE, with more than 10% ethanol, or ETHANOL AND PETROL MIXTURE, with more than 10% ethanol, and

Subparagraph.Label: (xi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3494, PETROLEUM SOUR CRUDE OIL, FLAMMABLE, TOXIC; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any quantity of dangerous goods that are Risk Group 4 human pathogens within the meaning of the Human Pathogens and Toxins Act.

Subsection.Text: Any substance that would require an ERAP if its classification were determined in accordance with Part 2 (Classification) requires an approved ERAP if its appropriate classification in the ICAO Technical Instructions, the IMDG Code or the UN Recommendations is to be used under subsection 2.2(4).

Heading.TitleText: Application for Approval of an ERAP

Subsection.Text: A person must apply to the Minister in writing for the approval of an ERAP.
The application for approval must be signed by the applicant and must include a copy of the ERAP and the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and contact information of the applicant;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the applicant’s operations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name and contact information of any third party who assisted in the preparation of the application;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the classification of the dangerous goods to which the ERAP relates and the mode of transport used;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: for each mode of transport used,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the frequency of the transportation of the dangerous goods,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the type and specification of the means of containment used to transport the dangerous goods, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the geographical area in which the dangerous goods are transported;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the ERAP telephone number, including the area code, at which a person identified in the ERAP can be reached at any time while the dangerous goods are handled or transported;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the communications systems that will be available at the location of a release or anticipated release of dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the name and contact information of any third-party emergency responders, their role and a copy of the agreement between the applicant and the third party;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the following information regarding the ERAP response equipment:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a detailed list of the equipment,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the location of the equipment,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the name of the person responsible for the operation of the equipment at each location,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: for each location, the dangerous goods in respect of which the equipment is to be used during emergency measures, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the geographical areas where the equipment at each location is to be used;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the following information respecting the ERAP response personnel, including technical advisors, team leaders and response teams:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: their names and contact information,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: their responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: any training they have taken, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: description of their knowledge and experience in respect of the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the response capability in respect of the dangerous goods, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the measures that can be taken in response to the release or anticipated release,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the persons responsible for taking the measures referred to in subparagraph (i), and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the ERAP equipment that will be used to take those measures;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: an estimate of the time required for the response personnel and equipment to reach the location of the release or anticipated release and a description of the mobilization and deployment steps in respect of the response personnel and equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: a potential incident analysis, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the following scenarios:

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: an anticipated release of dangerous goods,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the release of less than 1% of the dangerous goods in a means of containment,

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: the release of more than 50% of the dangerous goods in a means of containment, and

Clause.Label: (D)
Clause.Text: the exposure to fire of a means of containment that contains dangerous goods,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the possible consequences of the release or anticipated release for each scenario,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the measures, organized by tier in accordance with section 7.8, to be taken in response to the release or anticipated release for each scenario, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the identification of the persons responsible for taking the measures referred to in subparagraph (iii).

Heading.TitleText: Application for Approval of an ERAP – Emergency Response Contractors

Section.Text: A person who is not required to have an approved ERAP under subsection 7(1) of the Act, but who is able to take measures to respond to a release or anticipated release of dangerous goods for the purposes of paragraph 7.1(b) of the Act, may apply to the Minister in writing for the approval of an ERAP. The application must include a copy of the ERAP and the information referred to in paragraphs 7.3(2)(a), (b), (d), (g) and (i) to (l).

Heading.TitleText: Application for Approval of Changes to Approved ERAP

Subsection.Text: A person with an approved ERAP must, as soon as possible, apply to the Minister in writing for an approval of changes if any of the information referred to in paragraphs 7.3(2)(a) to (l) has changed since its approval.
The application referred to in subsection (1) must be signed by the applicant and include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the ERAP; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the information referred to in paragraphs 7.3(2)(a) to (l) that has changed.

Subsection.Text: A person may request a review of the decision to refuse an application for approval of an ERAP or to revoke an ERAP approval within 30 days after being notified of the decision.
The request must be made to the Minister in writing and must include the reasons why the decision should be revised.

Heading.TitleText: Authorization to Use an Approved ERAP

Subsection.Text: A person who is required to have an ERAP under subsection 7(1) of the Act may use, as an authorized user, the ERAP of another person who received approval for the ERAP if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the authorized user is not the producer of the dangerous goods to which the ERAP relates;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the ERAP applies to the dangerous goods, the mode of transport, the means of containment and the geographical area in which the dangerous goods will be in transport;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person who received approval for the ERAP agrees to take measures to respond to a release or anticipated release of the dangerous goods to which the ERAP relates; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the person who received approval for the ERAP provides a written authorization to the authorized user before the information referred to in subsection 3.6(1) is entered on the shipping document.

Subsection.Text: The authorized user must be able to produce a copy of the authorization referred to in paragraph (1)(d)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for two years after the day on which the authorization is no longer in effect; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: within 15 days after the day on which the authorized user receives a written request from the Minister.

Subsection.Text: A person with an approved ERAP must implement it to tier 1 or tier 2 in response to a release or anticipated release of dangerous goods.
A person who implements an approved ERAP to tier 1 must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide technical or emergency response advice as soon as possible after a request for the advice; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: remotely monitor the response to the release or anticipated release.

Subsection.Text: A person who implements an approved ERAP to tier 2 must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide technical or emergency response advice as soon as possible after a request for the advice;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: monitor the response to the release or anticipated release; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: send ERAP emergency response resources to the location of the release or anticipated release.

Subsection.Text: A person must not prevent another person who has an approved ERAP from taking emergency measures in response to a release or anticipated release.

Heading.TitleText: Compensation for the Authorized Implementation of an Approved ERAP

Subsection.Text: If a person implements an approved ERAP in accordance with paragraph 7.1(b) of the Act, the following expenses are authorized for the purposes of compensation under section 7.2 of the Act:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: expenses related to the death, disability or injury of the person or to the death, disability or injury of any of the person’s employees or contractors if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the person, the employee or the contractor is killed, disabled or injured during the implementation of the ERAP, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the death, disability or injury is the result of an act or omission that was committed by the person in good faith and without negligence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the cost of the person’s employees or contractors who are reasonably required to implement the ERAP;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the cost of using the person’s tools and other equipment, such as vehicles, pumps, hoses and generators, that are reasonably required to implement the ERAP;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: travel expenses, such as those incurred for meals, accommodation, fuel, oil and flights, for persons who are reasonably required to implement the ERAP;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: rental fees for heavy equipment, such as cranes, bulldozers, pumps, compressors and generators, that are reasonably required to implement the ERAP;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: other overhead costs that can reasonably be attributed to the implementation of the ERAP;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the cost of repairing tools and other equipment that are damaged during the implementation of the ERAP;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the cost of replacing

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: single-use equipment and supplies, such as packaging, personal protective equipment, personal protective clothing, chemicals and other consumables, that are reasonably required to implement the ERAP,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: tools and other equipment that are lost during the implementation of the ERAP, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: tools and other equipment that are damaged beyond repair during the implementation of the ERAP;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the cost of repairing or replacing personal property or movables or real property or immovables that have to be damaged to implement the ERAP;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the cost of defending any legal action for which there is no personal liability under paragraph 20(c) of the Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the cost of cleaning up after an incident, including handling and disposal costs for dangerous goods and contaminated materials.

Subsection.Text: The following expenses are not authorized for the purposes of compensation under section 7.2 of the Act:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the cost of purchasing new equipment to implement the approved ERAP; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the cost of lost business or production during the implementation of the approved ERAP.

Subsection.Text: Compensation under paragraph 7.9(1)(a) is limited to the compensation that would be paid in relation to the dead, disabled or injured person if the person were insured under

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Public Service Management Insurance Plan;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Public Service Health Care Plan, with hospital coverage at level III; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Public Service Dental Care Plan.

Subsection.Text: Compensation under paragraph 7.9(1)(h) in relation to the replacement of the items listed in subparagraphs 7.9(1)(h)(i), (ii) and (iii) is limited to the cost of an item of equivalent capability and quality.

Compensation under paragraph 7.9(1)(i) in relation to damaged property is limited to the fair market value of the property immediately before it is damaged by the person who implements the approved ERAP.

Section.Text: Claims for compensation must be submitted with supporting documentation to the Minister no later than three months after completion of the emergency response work.
This Part applies in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the release or anticipated release of dangerous goods that are being offered for transport, handled or transported by road vehicle, railway vehicle or vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the release or anticipated release of dangerous goods that are being offered for transport, handled or transported by aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: undeclared and misdeclared dangerous goods that are being offered for transport, handled or transported by aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the loss or theft of dangerous goods; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: unlawful interference with dangerous goods.

Heading.TitleText: Emergency Report — Road, Rail or Marine

Section.Text: A person who is required by subsection 18(1) of the Act to report a release or anticipated release of dangerous goods that are being offered for transport, handled or transported by road vehicle, railway vehicle or vessel must, as soon as possible after a release or anticipated release, make an emergency report to any local authority that is responsible for responding to emergencies at the geographic location of the release or anticipated release if the dangerous goods are, or could be, in excess of the quantity set out in the following table:

row.entry: A level of ionizing radiation greater than the level established in section 39 of the Packaging and Transport of Nuclear Substances Regulations, 2015
II or III, or without packing group

Heading.TitleText: Information To Be Included in an Emergency Report — Road, Rail or Marine

Section.Text: An emergency report referred to in section 8.2 must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and contact information of the person making the report;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a release of dangerous goods, the date, time and geographic location of the release;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an anticipated release of dangerous goods, the date, time and geographic location of the incident that led to the anticipated release;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the mode of transport used;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the shipping name or UN number of the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of dangerous goods that was in the means of containment before the release or anticipated release;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a release of dangerous goods, the quantity of dangerous goods estimated to have been released; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the type of incident leading to the release or anticipated release, including a collision, roll-over, derailment, overfill, fire, explosion or load-shift.

Heading.TitleText: Release or Anticipated Release Report — Road, Rail or Marine

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), a person who has made an emergency report referred to in section 8.2 must, as soon as possible after making it, make a report to the persons listed in subsection (4).
Subject to subsection (3), the person is not required to make a report referred to in subsection (1) if the release or anticipated release did not result in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the death of a person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person sustaining injuries that required immediate medical treatment by a health care provider;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an evacuation of people or their shelter in place; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the closure of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a facility used in the loading and unloading of dangerous goods, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a road, a main railway line or a main waterway.

Subsection.Text: The person is required to make a report referred to in subsection (1) if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a means of containment has been damaged to the extent that its integrity is compromised; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the centre sill or stub sill of a tank car is broken or there is a crack in the metal equal to or greater than 15 cm (6 in.).

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), the persons to whom a report must be made are

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the consignor of the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of dangerous goods included in Class 7, Radioactive Materials, the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a vessel, a Vessel Traffic Services Centre or a Canadian Coast Guard radio station.

Heading.TitleText: Information To Be Included in a Release or Anticipated Release Report — Road, Rail or Marine

Section.Text: A release or anticipated release report referred to in section 8.4 must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and contact information of the person making the report;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a release of dangerous goods, the date, time and geographic location of the release;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an anticipated release of dangerous goods, the date, time and geographic location of the incident that led to the anticipated release;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the mode of transport used;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the shipping name or UN number of the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of dangerous goods that was in the means of containment before the release or anticipated release;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a release of dangerous goods, the quantity of dangerous goods estimated to have been released;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the type of incident leading to the release or anticipated release, including a collision, rollover, derailment, overfill, fire, explosion or load-shift;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the name and geographic location of any road, main railway line or main waterway that was closed;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the means of containment containing the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, an estimate of the number of people evacuated or sheltered in place; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the number of deaths and the number of persons who sustained injuries that required immediate medical treatment by a health care provider.

Section.Text: A person who has made a report referred to in section 8.4, or the person’s employer, must make a follow-up report in writing to the Minister within 30 days after the day on which the report was made.

Heading.TitleText: Information To Be Included in a 30-Day Follow-up Report

Section.Text: A follow-up report referred to in section 8.6 must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and contact information of the person making the report;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the names and contact information of the consignor, consignee and carrier;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a release of dangerous goods, the date, time and geographic location of the release;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an anticipated release of dangerous goods, the date, time and geographic location of the incident that led to the anticipated release;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the mode of transport used;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the classification of the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of dangerous goods that was in the means of containment before the release or anticipated release;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a release of dangerous goods, the quantity of dangerous goods estimated to have been released;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the means of containment containing the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, a description of any failure of or damage to the means of containment;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: information about the events leading to the release or anticipated release of dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: information as to whether there was an explosion or fire;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: the name and geographic location of any facility used in the loading or unloading of the dangerous goods that was closed, and the duration of the closure;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: the name and geographic location of any road, main railway line or main waterway that was closed, and the duration of the closure;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, an estimate of the number of people evacuated or sheltered in place and the duration of the evacuation or shelter in place;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the number of deaths and the number of persons who sustained injuries that required immediate medical treatment by a health care provider;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: the ERAP reference number, if applicable, and

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the name of the person who was required to have the ERAP under subsection 7(1) of the Act, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the date and time that the ERAP incident report referred to in section 8.20 was made;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the report referred to in section 8.4 was made; and

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: an estimate of any financial loss incurred as a result of the release or anticipated release, and any emergency response cost or remediation costs related to it.

Heading.TitleText: 30-Day Follow-up Report — Notice and Retention of Report

Subsection.Text: A person who has made a follow-up report referred to in section 8.6 must, as soon as possible, notify the Minister of any change to the information referred to in paragraph 8.7(f), (i), (j), (k), (l), (p) or (s) that occurs within one year after the day on which the follow-up report was made.
The person must keep a copy of the report for two years after the day on which it is made.
The person must make the report available to an inspector within 15 days after the day on which the person receives a written request from the inspector.

Heading.TitleText: Dangerous Goods Accident or Incident Report — Air

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), a person who is required by subsection 18(1) of the Act to report a release or anticipated release of dangerous goods that are being offered for transport, handled or transported at an aerodrome, at an air cargo facility or by aircraft must as soon as possible after a release or anticipated release, make a report if the dangerous goods are, or could be, in excess of the quantity set out in the following table:

row.entry: A level of ionizing radiation greater than the level established in section 39 of the Packaging and Transport of Nuclear Substances Regulations, 2015

Subsection.Text: The report referred to in subsection (1) must be made to CANUTEC, at 1-888-CANUTEC (1-888-226-8832) or 613-996-6666, and, in the case of dangerous goods included in Class 7, Radioactive Materials, to the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission.
The person is not required to make the report referred to in subsection (1) if the release or anticipated release does not result in any of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the death or injury of a person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: damage to property or to the environment;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: signs that the integrity of a means of containment has been compromised, including signs of fire, of breakage or of fluid or radiation leakage;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: serious jeopardy to persons on an aircraft or to the aircraft itself;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an evacuation of people or their shelter in place; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the closure of an aerodrome, air cargo facility or runway.

Heading.TitleText: Information To Be Included in a Dangerous Goods Accident or Incident Report — Air

Section.Text: A report referred to in section 8.9 must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and contact information of the person making the report;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a release of dangerous goods, the date, time and geographic location of the release;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an anticipated release of dangerous goods, the date, time and geographic location of the incident that led to the anticipated release;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the aircraft operator, aerodrome or air cargo facility;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the shipping name or UN number of the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of dangerous goods that was in the means of containment before the release or anticipated release;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a release of dangerous goods, the quantity of dangerous goods estimated to have been released;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the type of incident leading to the release or anticipated release;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the means of containment containing the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the number of deaths and the number of persons who sustained injuries; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, an estimate of the number of people evacuated or sheltered in place.

Section.Text: A person who has made a report referred to in section 8.9, or the person’s employer, must make a follow-up report in writing to the Minister within 30 days after the day on which the report was made.

Heading.TitleText: Information To Be Included in a 30-Day Follow-up Report

Section.Text: A follow-up report referred to in section 8.11 must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and contact information of the person making the report;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the names and contact information of the consignor, consignee and aircraft operator;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a release of dangerous goods, the date, time and geographic location of the release;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an anticipated release of dangerous goods, the date, time and geographic location of the incident that led to the anticipated release;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the classification of the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of dangerous goods that was in the means of containment before the release or anticipated release;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a release of dangerous goods, the quantity of dangerous goods estimated to have been released;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the means of containment containing the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, a description of any failure of or damage to the means of containment;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: information about the events leading to the release or anticipated release of dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: information as to whether there was an explosion or fire;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the name and geographic location of any aerodrome, air cargo facility or runway that was closed, and the duration of the closure;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, an estimate of the number of people evacuated or sheltered in place, and the duration of the evacuation or shelter in place;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the number of deaths and the number of persons who sustained injuries;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the ERAP reference number;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the report referred to in section 8.9 was made;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: an estimate of any financial loss incurred as a result of the release or anticipated release, and any emergency response costs or remediation costs related to it;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the route by which the dangerous goods were to be transported, including the names of any aerodromes along the route;

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any serious jeopardy to persons on any aircraft or to the aircraft itself; and

Paragraph.Label: (t)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any damage to property or to the environment.

Heading.TitleText: 30-Day Follow-up Report — Notice and Retention of Report

Subsection.Text: A person who has made a follow-up report referred to in section 8.11 must, as soon as possible, notify the Minister of any change to the information referred to in paragraph 8.12(e), (h), (i), (k), (n) or (q) that occurs within one year after the day on which the follow-up report was made.
The person must keep a copy of the report for two years after the day on which it is made.
The person must make the report available to an inspector within 15 days after the day on which the person receives a written request from the inspector.

Heading.TitleText: Undeclared or Misdeclared Dangerous Goods Report

Section.Text: A person must make a report to CANUTEC, at 1-888-CANUTEC (1-888-226-8832) or 613-996-6666, as soon as possible after discovering, at an aerodrome or air cargo facility or on board an aircraft, dangerous goods that are not accompanied by the documentation or dangerous goods marks set out for the dangerous goods in Parts 1 to 6 and 8 of the ICAO Technical Instructions.

Heading.TitleText: Information To Be Included in an Undeclared or Misdeclared Dangerous Goods Report

Section.Text: A report referred to in section 8.14 must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and contact information of the person making the report;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the aircraft operator, aerodrome or air cargo facility;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the names and contact information of the consignor and consignee;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the discovery of the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the shipping name or UN number of the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the means of containment containing the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the gross mass or capacity of the means of containment and, if applicable, the total number of means of containment; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the route by which the dangerous goods were to be transported, including the names of any aerodromes along the route.

Section.Text: A person must make a dangerous goods occurrence report (ICAO) to the Minister within seven days after discovering, at an aerodrome or air cargo facility or on board an aircraft, dangerous goods that have been transported on board an aircraft without

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: being loaded, segregated or secured in accordance with Chapter 2 of Part 7 of the ICAO Technical Instructions; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command having been informed in accordance with section 7;4.1 of the ICAO Technical Instructions.

Heading.TitleText: Information To Be Included in a Dangerous Goods Occurrence Report (ICAO)

Section.Text: A dangerous goods occurrence report (ICAO) referred to in section 8.15.1 must be in writing and include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and contact information of the person making the report;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the aircraft operator, aerodrome or air cargo facility;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the names and contact information of the consignor and consignee;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the discovery of the occurrence referred to in paragraph 8.15.1(a) or (b);

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the shipping name or UN number of the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the means of containment containing the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the gross mass or capacity of the means of containment and, if applicable, the total number of means of containment;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the route by which the dangerous goods were, or were to be, transported, including the names of any aerodromes along the route; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a detailed description of the circumstances that led to the discovery of the occurrence referred to in paragraph 8.15.1(a) or (b), as the case may be.

Subsection.Text: A person who is required by subsection 18(3) of the Act to report the loss or theft of dangerous goods must, as soon as possible after the loss or theft, report it by telephone to the persons listed in subsection (3) if the lost or stolen dangerous goods are in excess of the quantity set out in subsection (2).
For the purposes of subsection (1), the quantities of dangerous goods are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any quantity, in the case of the following dangerous goods:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1261, NITROMETHANE,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1357, UREA NITRATE, WETTED, with not less than 20% water, by mass,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1485, POTASSIUM CHLORATE,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1486, POTASSIUM NITRATE,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1487, POTASSIUM NITRATE AND SODIUM NITRITE MIXTURE,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1489, POTASSIUM PERCHLORATE,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1495, SODIUM CHLORATE,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1498, SODIUM NITRATE,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1499, SODIUM NITRATE AND POTASSIUM NITRATE MIXTURE,

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1511, UREA HYDROGEN PEROXIDE,

Subparagraph.Label: (xi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1796, NITRATING ACID MIXTURE with more than 50% nitric acid,

Subparagraph.Label: (xii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1826, NITRATING ACID MIXTURE, SPENT, with more than 50% nitric acid,

Subparagraph.Label: (xiii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN1942, AMMONIUM NITRATE with not more than 0.2% combustible substances, including any organic substance calculated as carbon, to the exclusion of any other added substance,

Subparagraph.Label: (xiv)
Subparagraph.Text: UN2014, HYDROGEN PEROXIDE, AQUEOUS SOLUTION with not less than 20% but not more than 60% hydrogen peroxide (stabilized as necessary),

Subparagraph.Label: (xv)
Subparagraph.Text: UN2015, HYDROGEN PEROXIDE, AQUEOUS SOLUTION, STABILIZED with more than 60% hydrogen peroxide, or HYDROGEN PEROXIDE, STABILIZED,

Subparagraph.Label: (xvi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN2031, NITRIC ACID, other than red fuming,

Subparagraph.Label: (xvii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN2032, NITRIC ACID, RED FUMING,

Subparagraph.Label: (xviii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3149, HYDROGEN PEROXIDE AND PEROXYACETIC ACID MIXTURE with acid(s), water and not more than 5% peroxyacetic acid, STABILIZED, and

Subparagraph.Label: (xix)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3370, UREA NITRATE, WETTED, with not less than 10% water by mass;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any quantity, in the case of dangerous goods in the following primary and subsidiary classes:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: explosives included in Class 1.1, 1.2 or 1.3,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: toxic gases included in Class 2.3,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: organic peroxides included in Class 5.2, Type B, liquid or solid, temperature controlled,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: toxic substances included in Class 6.1 and Packing Group I,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: infectious substances included in Class 6.2, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: radioactive materials included in Class 7; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a total quantity of 450 kg or more, in the case of dangerous goods in the following primary and subsidiary classes:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: explosives included in Class 1.4 (except for 1.4S), 1.5 or 1.6,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: flammable gases included in Class 2.1,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: flammable liquids included in Class 3,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: desensitized explosives included in Class 3 or 4.1,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: substances liable to spontaneous combustion, pyrophoric solids or liquids, included in Class 4.2 and Packing Group I or II,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: water-reactive substances included in Class 4.3 and Packing Group I or II,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: oxidizing substances included in Class 5.1 and Packing Group I or II, and

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: corrosives included in Class 8 and Packing Group I or II.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), the persons to whom the report must be made are

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of dangerous goods included in Class 1, Explosives, or referred to in paragraph (2)(a) or subparagraph (2)(b)(i) or (c)(i), a Natural Resources Canada inspector, at 613-995-5555; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of dangerous goods included in Class 7, Radioactive Materials, the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission.

Subsection.Text: A person who made the report referred to in subsection (1) must notify the persons referred to in subsection (3) if that person finds the dangerous goods that were lost or stolen.

Heading.TitleText: Information To Be Included in a Loss or Theft Report

Section.Text: A loss or theft report referred to in section 8.16 must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and contact information of the person making the report;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the names and contact information of the consignor, the consignee and the carrier;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: information as to whether the dangerous goods were lost or stolen;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the shipping name or UN number of the lost or stolen dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of the lost or stolen dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the means of containment containing the lost or stolen dangerous goods; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the approximate date, time and geographic location of the loss or theft.

Subsection.Text: If there has been unlawful interference with dangerous goods while they were being imported, offered for transport, handled or transported, the person who had the charge, management or control of the goods must, as soon as possible after the discovery of the unlawful interference, report it by telephone to the persons listed in subsection (2).
For the purposes of subsection (1), the persons to whom the unlawful interference must be reported are

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of dangerous goods included in Class 1, Explosives, or referred to in paragraph 8.16(2)(a) or subparagraph 8.16(2)(b)(i) or (c)(i), a Natural Resources Canada inspector, at 613-995-5555; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of dangerous goods included in Class 7, Radioactive Materials, the Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission.

Heading.TitleText: Information To Be Included in an Unlawful Interference Report

Section.Text: A report referred to in section 8.18 must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and contact information of the person making the report;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the names and contact information of the consignor, the consignee and the carrier;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a detailed description of the unlawful interference;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the shipping name or UN number of the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the means of containment containing the dangerous goods, and the number of means of containment; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the approximate date, time and geographic location of the unlawful interference.

Section.Text: A person who is required under subsection 18(1) of the Act to report a release or anticipated release of dangerous goods in respect of which an approved ERAP is required under subsection 7(1) of the Act must, as soon as possible after the release or anticipated release, make an ERAP incident report by telephone to the person at the ERAP telephone number required to be included on the shipping document under paragraph 3.6(1)(b), if the dangerous goods are, or could be, in excess of the quantity set out in the following table:

row.entry: A level of ionizing radiation greater than the level established in section 39 of the Packaging and Transport of Nuclear Substances Regulations, 2015

Heading.TitleText: Information To Be Included in an ERAP Incident Report

Section.Text: An ERAP incident report referred to in section 8.20 must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and contact information of the person making the report;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the ERAP reference number;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a release of dangerous goods, the date, time and geographic location of the release;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an anticipated release of dangerous goods, the date, time and geographic location of the incident that led to the anticipated release;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the mode of transport used;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the shipping name or UN number of the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of dangerous goods that was in the means of containment before the release or anticipated release;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a release, the quantity of dangerous goods estimated to have been released;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the means of containment containing the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: an indication of whether a means of containment has been damaged to the extent that its integrity could be compromised;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: an indication of whether a transfer of the dangerous goods to another means of containment is anticipated or required; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the type of incident leading to the release or anticipated release, including a collision, rollover, derailment, overfill, fire, explosion or load-shift.

Section.Text: Each time a person implements an approved ERAP to tier 1 or tier 2, the person must, as soon as possible, make an ERAP implementation report to CANUTEC, at 1-888-CANUTEC (1-888‑226‑8832) or 613‑996‑6666.

Heading.TitleText: Information To Be Included in an ERAP Implementation Report

Section.Text: An ERAP implementation report referred to in section 8.22 must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and contact information of the person making the report;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the ERAP reference number;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the person authorized under subsection 7.7(1) to use the ERAP;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: whether the ERAP was implemented to tier 1 or 2;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the date and time that the ERAP was implemented to tier 1 or 2;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the shipping name or UN number of the dangerous goods in relation to which the ERAP was implemented; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the measures taken to respond to the release or anticipated release.

Heading.TitleText: Transporting Dangerous Goods from the United States into or through Canada

Subsection.Text: Despite the requirements in Part 2 (Classification), Part 3 (Documentation) and Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks), a person may handle or transport dangerous goods by road vehicle from a place in the United States to a place in Canada or from a place in the United States through Canada to a place outside Canada in accordance with the classification, marking, labelling, placarding and documentation requirements of 49 CFR, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the information required on the shipping document is easy to identify, legible, in indelible print, in English or French and includes

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: when dangerous goods are transported to a place in Canada, the name and address of the place of business in Canada of the consignor,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: when dangerous goods are transported from a place in the United States through Canada to a place outside Canada, the name and the address of the place of business of each consignor, except that in this case the name and address may be shown on a separate document attached to the shipping document and is required only while that person is the consignor,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the classification in Schedule 1 or in the UN Recommendations, for dangerous goods that have the letter “D” assigned to them in column 1 of the table to section 172.101 of 49 CFR, except for dangerous goods with the shipping name “Consumer commodity”, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: if applicable, the information relating to the approved ERAP referred to in subsection 3.6(1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person complies with the following sections in Part 3 (Documentation):

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.2, Carrier responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.7, Location of a shipping document: road, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.10, Location of a shipping document: storage in the course of transportation; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: on or after August 31, 2008, the labels and placards displayed for dangerous goods included in Class 2.3 or Class 6.1 are the labels and placards required in these Regulations for the dangerous goods. The labels and placards may be displayed before August 31, 2008.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply to dangerous goods that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are forbidden for transport by these Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are not regulated by 49 CFR but are regulated by these Regulations; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: are given dangerous goods safety mark or packaging exceptions in 49 CFR that are not permitted by these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: A person who handles or transports dangerous goods by road vehicle in accordance with an exemption issued under Subpart B of Part 107 of 49 CFR may do so from a place in the United States to a place in Canada or from a place in the United States through Canada to a place outside Canada if the exemption number appears on the shipping document.

If there is a conflict between the requirements of Part 2 (Classification), Part 3 (Documentation), Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks) or Part 5 (Means of Containment) and an exemption referred to in subsection (3), the exemption prevails to the extent of the conflict.

Heading.TitleText: Transporting Dangerous Goods to or from an Aircraft, an Aerodrome or an Air Cargo Facility

Subsection.Text: Despite the requirements in Part 2 (Classification), Part 3 (Documentation), and Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks), if transport has been or is to be by aircraft, a person may handle or transport dangerous goods by road vehicle to or from an aircraft, an aerodrome or an air cargo facility in accordance with the classification, marking, labelling, and documentation requirements of the ICAO Technical Instructions, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the information required on the shipping document is easy to identify, legible, in indelible print, in English or French and includes, if applicable, the information relating to the approved ERAP referred to in subsection 3.6(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person complies with the following provisions in Part 3 (Documentation):

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.2, Carrier responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraph 3.5(1)(f) and subsection 3.5(2), concerning a 24-hour number on a shipping document,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.7, Location of a shipping document: road, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.10, Location of a shipping document: storage in the course of transportation.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply if these Regulations forbid the transport of the dangerous goods or if the dangerous goods are not regulated by the ICAO Technical Instructions but are regulated by these Regulations.

When dangerous goods are transported to or from an aircraft, an aerodrome or an air cargo facility, by a road vehicle, the road vehicle, or any means of containment visible from outside the road vehicle, must have placards displayed on it in accordance with Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks).

Heading.TitleText: Transporting Dangerous Goods to or from a Vessel, a Port Facility or a Marine Terminal

Subsection.Text: Despite the requirements in Part 2 (Classification), Part 3 (Documentation), and Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks), if transport has been or is to be by vessel, a person may handle or transport by road vehicle an international consignment of dangerous goods to or from a vessel, a port facility or a marine terminal in accordance with the classification, marking, labelling, placarding and documentation requirements of the IMDG Code if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the information required on the shipping document is easy to identify, legible, in indelible print, in English or French and includes, if applicable, the information relating to the approved ERAP referred to in subsection 3.6(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person complies with the following provisions in Part 3 (Documentation):

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.2, Carrier responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraph 3.5(1)(f) and subsection 3.5(2), concerning a 24-hour number on a shipping document,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.7, Location of a shipping document: road, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.10, Location of a shipping document: storage in the course of transportation.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply if these Regulations forbid the transport of the dangerous goods or if the dangerous goods are not regulated by the IMDG Code but are regulated by these Regulations.

When dangerous goods are transported in a large means of containment to or from a vessel, a port facility or a marine terminal, the large means of containment must have placards displayed on it in accordance with Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks) or the IMDG Code.

When a consignment of dangerous goods is transported from a place outside Canada to a place in Canada and is reshipped within Canada by road vehicle, the dangerous goods safety marks displayed in accordance with 49 CFR, the ICAO Technical Instructions or the IMDG Code at the time of entry into Canada may continue to be displayed, except that the large means of containment containing the dangerous goods must have placards displayed on it in accordance with Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks).

The shipping document that accompanies the dangerous goods must include a notation that the dangerous goods safety marks are in accordance with 49 CFR, the ICAO Technical Instructions or the IMDG Code, if they differ from the ones required to be displayed by Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks).

Heading.TitleText: Maximum Net Explosives Quantity in a Road Vehicle

Section.Text: The total net explosives quantity of all explosives that are transported together in a road vehicle must be less than or equal to the following limits:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 25 kg if any of the explosives are UN0190, SAMPLES, EXPLOSIVE;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 2 000 kg if any of the explosives are included in Class 1.1A; and

Heading.TitleText: Transporting Dangerous Goods from the United States into or through Canada

Subsection.Text: Despite the requirements in Part 2 (Classification), Part 3 (Documentation) and Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks), a person may handle or transport dangerous goods by railway vehicle from a place in the United States to a place in Canada or from a place in the United States through Canada to a place outside Canada in accordance with the classification, marking, labelling, placarding and documentation requirements of 49 CFR if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the information required on the shipping document is easy to identify, legible, in indelible print, in English or French and includes

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: when dangerous goods are transported to a place in Canada, the name and address of the place of business in Canada of the consignor,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: when dangerous goods are transported from a place in the United States through Canada to a place outside Canada, the name and the address of the place of business of each consignor, except that in this case the name and address may be shown on a separate document attached to the shipping document and is required only while that person is the consignor,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the classification in Schedule 1 or in the UN Recommendations, for dangerous goods that have the letter “D” assigned to them in column 1 of the table to section 172.101 of 49 CFR, except for dangerous goods with the shipping name “Consumer commodity”, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: if applicable, the information relating to the approved ERAP referred to in subsection 3.6(1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person complies with the following sections in Part 3 (Documentation):

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.2, Carrier responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.8, Location of a shipping document and consist: rail, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.10, Location of a shipping document: storage in the course of transportation, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: on or after August 31, 2008, the labels and placards displayed for dangerous goods included in Class 2.3 or 6.1 are the labels and placards required in these Regulations for the dangerous goods. The labels or placards may be displayed before August 31, 2008.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply to dangerous goods that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are forbidden for transport by these Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are not regulated by 49 CFR but are regulated by these Regulations; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: are given dangerous goods safety mark or packaging exceptions in 49 CFR that are not permitted by these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: A person who handles or transports dangerous goods by railway vehicle in accordance with an exemption issued under Subpart B of Part 107 of 49 CFR may do so from a place in the United States to a place in Canada or from a place in the United States through Canada to a place outside Canada if the exemption number appears on the shipping document.

If there is a conflict between the requirements of Part 2 (Classification), Part 3 (Documentation), Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks) or Part 5 (Means of Containment) and an exemption referred to in subsection (3), the exemption prevails to the extent of the conflict.

Section.Text: Despite the requirements of Part 5 (Means of Containment), a person may offer for transport, handle or transport dangerous goods by railway vehicle from a place in the United States to a place in Canada or from a place in the United States through Canada to a place outside Canada in accordance with the requirements of Parts 172, 173, 174, 179 and 180 of 49 CFR, except by tank car if the goods are Class 3, Flammable Liquids that are referred to in section 10.5.6 of TP 14877.

Heading.TitleText: Transporting Dangerous Goods to or from an Aircraft, an Aerodrome or an Air Cargo Facility

Subsection.Text: Despite the requirements in Part 2 (Classification), Part 3 (Documentation) and Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks), if transport has been or is to be by aircraft, a person may handle or transport dangerous goods by railway vehicle to or from an aircraft, an aerodrome or an air cargo facility in accordance with the classification, marking, labelling and documentation requirements of the ICAO Technical Instructions, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the information required on the shipping document is easy to identify, legible, in indelible print, in English or French and includes, if applicable, the information relating to the approved ERAP referred to in subsection 3.6(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person complies with the following provisions in Part 3 (Documentation):

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.2, Carrier responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraph 3.5(1)(f) and subsection 3.5(2), concerning a 24-hour number on a shipping document,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.8, Location of a shipping document and consist: rail, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.10, Location of a shipping document: storage in the course of transportation.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply if these Regulations forbid the transport of the dangerous goods or if the dangerous goods are not regulated by the ICAO Technical Instructions but are regulated by these Regulations.

When dangerous goods are transported to or from an aircraft, an aerodrome or an air cargo facility, by railway vehicle, the railway vehicle, or any means of containment visible from outside the railway vehicle must have placards displayed on it in accordance with Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks).

Heading.TitleText: Transporting Dangerous Goods to or from a Vessel, a Port Facility or a Marine Terminal

Subsection.Text: Despite the requirements in Part 2 (Classification), Part 3 (Documentation), and Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks), if transport has been or is to be by vessel, a person may handle an international consignment of dangerous goods or transport it by railway vehicle to or from a vessel, a port facility or a marine terminal in accordance with the classification, marking, labelling, placarding and documentation requirements of the IMDG Code if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the information required on the shipping document is easy to identify, legible, in indelible print, in English or French and includes, if applicable, the information relating to the approved ERAP referred to in subsection 3.6(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person complies with the following provisions in Part 3 (Documentation):

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.2, Carrier responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraph 3.5(1)(f) and subsection 3.5(2), concerning a 24-hour number on a shipping document,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.8, Location of a shipping document and consist: rail, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.10, Location of a shipping document: storage in the course of transportation.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply if these Regulations forbid the transport of the dangerous goods or if the dangerous goods are not regulated by the IMDG Code but are regulated by these Regulations.

When dangerous goods are transported in a large means of containment to or from a vessel, a port facility or a marine terminal, the large means of containment must have placards displayed on it in accordance with Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks) or the IMDG Code.

When a consignment of dangerous goods is transported from a place outside Canada to a place in Canada and is reshipped within Canada by railway vehicle, the dangerous goods safety marks displayed in accordance with 49 CFR, the ICAO Technical Instructions or the IMDG Code at the time of entry into Canada may continue to be displayed, except that the large means of containment containing the dangerous goods must have placards displayed on it in accordance with Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks).

The shipping document that accompanies the dangerous goods must include a notation that the dangerous goods safety marks are in accordance with 49 CFR, the ICAO Technical Instructions or the IMDG Code, if they differ from the ones required to be displayed by Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks).

Heading.TitleText: Location of Placarded Railway Vehicle in a Train

Subsection.Text: Unless it is likely to have a serious impact on train dynamics, a person must not, in a train, locate a railway vehicle that contains dangerous goods described in column 1 of the table to this subsection for which a placard is required to be displayed in accordance with Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks), next to a railway vehicle described in the same row in column 2.

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: an operating engine or an engine tender unless all the railway vehicles in the train, other than engines, tenders and cabooses, have placards displayed on them;

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: an occupied railway vehicle unless all the other railway vehicles in the train, other than engines, tenders and cabooses, are occupied or have placards displayed on them;
