Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: a railway vehicle that has a continual source of ignition; or

Provision.Label: (i)
Provision.Text: when the lading protrudes beyond the railway vehicle and may shift during transport, or

Provision.Label: (ii)
Provision.Text: when the lading is higher than the top of the railway vehicle and may shift during transport.

row.entry: Dangerous goods included in Class 1.1 or Class 1.2
Any railway vehicle that is required to have a placard displayed on it for Class 2, 3, 4 or 5

Provision.Text: UN1067, DINITROGEN TETROXIDE or NITROGEN DIOXIDE
UN1975, NITRIC OXIDE AND DINITROGEN TETROXIDE MIXTURE or NITRIC OXIDE AND NITROGEN DIOXIDE MIXTURE
UN2204, CARBONYL SULPHIDE or CARBONYL SULFIDE
UN3294, HYDROGEN CYANIDE, SOLUTION IN ALCOHOL

row.entry: Any railway vehicle that is required to have a placard displayed on it for Class 1, 2, 3, 4 or 5 unless the railway vehicle next to it contains the same dangerous goods

Subsection.Text: Dangerous goods that are being transported in railway vehicles in a train from the United States to Canada or from the United States through Canada to a place outside Canada may be located in the train in accordance with sections 174.84 and 174.85 of 49 CFR.

A person must not couple a railway vehicle with another railway vehicle at a relative coupling speed greater than 9.6 km/h (6 mph) if either of the railway vehicles that make contact on coupling contains dangerous goods for which a placard is required to be displayed in accordance with Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks).

Despite subsection (1), a person may couple a single railway vehicle moving under its own momentum at a relative coupling speed less than or equal to 12 km/h (7.5 mph) when the ambient temperature is above -25ºC.

If a person couples a tank car that contains dangerous goods for which a placard is required to be displayed in accordance with Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks), with another railway vehicle and the three conditions in any one of the four rows set out in the table to this subsection apply, the person must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: visually inspect the underframe assembly and coupling and cushioning components of the tank car to ensure their integrity before the tank car is moved more than 2 km from the place where the coupling occurred; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: report, in writing, to the owner of the tank car within 10 days after the coupling and include a copy of the text of this section and information about any damage that compromises the integrity of the underframe assembly or draft gear of the tank car discovered as a result of the inspection.

row.entry: Combined Coupling Mass: Tank Car and Other Railway Vehicle, and their Contents, in Kilograms
Relative Coupling Speed: in Kilometres per hour

Subsection.Text: The owner of a tank car who receives the report must not use the tank car or permit the tank car to be used to transport dangerous goods, other than the dangerous goods that were contained in the tank car at the time of the coupling, until the tank car undergoes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a visual inspection and a structural integrity inspection in accordance with clause 9.5.6(a) and clause 9.5.7 of TP 14877; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for a tank car equipped with a stub sill, a stub sill inspection covering at least the following areas:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the termination of the stub sill reinforcement pad closest to the mid-point of the tank car and associated welds for a 30-cm length from that point back towards the other end of the pad,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: all welds

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: connecting the head brace to the stub sill,

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: between the head brace and the head reinforcement pad, and

Clause.Label: (C)
Clause.Text: between the tank and the head reinforcement pad and, if the head reinforcement pad is connected to the stub sill reinforcement pad, 2.5 cm past that connection towards the centre of the tank,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: all metal of the stub sill assembly, other than welds, from the body bolster to the coupler, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the draft gear pocket.

Subsection.Text: This section does not apply if either the tank car or the other railway vehicle that was coupled is equipped with a cushioning device designed for a displacement of 15 cm (6 in.) or more in compression and capable of limiting the maximum coupler force to 4 448 kilonewtons (1,000,000 lbf) when impacted at 16.1 km/h (10 mph) by a railway vehicle having a gross mass of 99 790 kg (220,000 lb).

Section.Text: A consignor shall, on reasonable notice given by the Minister, provide the Minister with the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the number of tank cars owned or leased by the consignor that meet the requirements of TP 14877 for TC117R tank cars;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of tank cars owned or leased by the consignor that meet the requirements of TP 14877 for TC117P tank cars;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number of tank cars owned or leased by the consignor and used for importing, offering for transport or handling dangerous goods included in Class 3, Flammable Liquids, that meet the requirements of TP 14877 for Class 111 tank cars; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the number of tank cars owned or leased by the consignor and used for importing, offering for transport or handling dangerous goods included in Class 3, Flammable Liquids, that meet the requirements of TP 14877 for enhanced Class 111 tank cars.

Subsection.Text: A person who imports, offers for transport, handles or transports dangerous goods by vessel must comply with the IMDG Code if the dangerous goods are in transport between

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: two points in Canada on a voyage during which

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the vessel goes more than 120 nautical miles from shore,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on the Atlantic coast, the vessel goes south of the port of New York, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: on the Pacific coast, the vessel goes south of Portland, Oregon;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Canada and another country, if the voyage is not an inland voyage or a sheltered waters voyage that is within the waters described in paragraphs (a) and (b) of the definition inland voyage in section 1 of the Vessel Safety Certificates Regulations; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: two points outside Canada on board a vessel registered in Canada.

Subsection.Text: In addition to the requirements in subsection (1), a person who offers for transport, handles or transports dangerous goods by vessel must do so in accordance with the following provisions of these Regulations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the following provisions in Part 3 (Documentation):

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.2, Carrier responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 3.4(1), Legibility and language,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraph 3.5(1)(f) and subsection 3.5(2), concerning a 24-hour number on a shipping document,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.9, Location of a shipping document: marine, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.10, Location of a shipping document: storage in the course of transportation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the following provisions in Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks):

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 4.2, Misleading dangerous goods safety marks,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 4.4, Consignor responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 4.5(1), Carrier responsibilities, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: section 4.6, Visibility, legibility and colour;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the following provisions in Part 5 (Means of Containment):

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 5.2, Requirements for a standardized means of containment to be in standard,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 5.3, Compliance marks on a means of containment,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 5.6, UN standardized means of containment, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: section 5.10, Means of containment for Class 2, Gases, and section 5.11, UN1950, AEROSOLS, and UN2037, GAS CARTRIDGES; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: Part 8 (Reporting Requirements).

Subsection.Text: The means of containment used to transport the dangerous goods must be designed, constructed, filled, closed, secured and maintained so that under normal conditions of transport, including handling, there will be no release of the dangerous goods that could endanger public safety.

Heading.TitleText: Marine Transport — Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations

Section.Text: A person who imports, offers for transport, handles or transports dangerous goods by vessel must comply with these Regulations if the dangerous goods are in transport between

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: two points in Canada on a voyage during which the vessel is always within 120 nautical miles from shore and

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: on the Atlantic coast, the vessel does not go south of the port of New York, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on the Pacific coast, the vessel does not go south of Portland, Oregon; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Canada and another country, if the voyage is an inland voyage or a sheltered waters voyage that is within the waters described in paragraphs (a) and (b) of the definition inland voyage in section 1 of the Vessel Safety Certificates Regulations.

Heading.TitleText: Transporting Dangerous Goods from One Country through Canada to Another Country

Section.Text: A person who transports dangerous goods by vessel from one country through Canada to another country must comply with the IMDG Code and Part 8 (Reporting Requirements) of these Regulations.

Heading.TitleText: International and Domestic Transport by Aircraft

Subsection.Text: A person who handles, offers for transport or transports dangerous goods by aircraft between Canada and another country must do so in accordance with the ICAO Technical Instructions and the following provisions of these Regulations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in Part 1 (Coming into Force, Repeal, Interpretation, General Provisions and Special Cases),

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 1.7, Safety requirements, documents, safety marks,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraphs 1.8(a) and (b), Prohibition: explosives,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 1.20, National Defence, and

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 1.43, Class 7, Radioactive Materials;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in Part 2 (Classification),

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 2.2, Responsibility for classification,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 2.36, Infectious substances,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 2.37, General, Class 7, Radioactive Materials, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: subparagraphs 2.43(b)(iv) and (v), concerning classifying in Class 9 dangerous goods that are environmentally hazardous substances;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in Part 3 (Documentation),

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.1, Consignor responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: subsections 3.2(1), (2), (3), (5) and (6), Carrier responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 3.4(1), Legibility and language,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraph 3.5(1)(f) and subsection 3.5(2), concerning a 24-hour number on a shipping document,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: subsections 3.6(1) and (2), which require the ERAP reference number and telephone number on a shipping document, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.11, Keeping shipping document information;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in Part 4 (Dangerous Goods Safety Marks),

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 4.2, Misleading dangerous goods safety marks,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 4.4, Consignor responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 4.5(1), Carrier responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: subsection 4.7(1), Labels and placards: size and orientation, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: section 4.9, Removal of dangerous goods safety marks;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in Part 5 (Means of Containment),

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: section 5.2, Requirements for a standardized means of containment to be in standard,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 5.3, Certification safety marks on a means of containment,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 5.6, UN standardized means of containment, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: section 5.10, Means of containment for Class 2, Gases;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: Part 6 (Training);

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: Part 7 (Emergency Response Assistance Plan);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: Part 8 (Reporting Requirements);

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: Part 13 (Protective Direction); and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: Part 14 (Permit for Equivalent Level of Safety).

Subsection.Text: A person who handles, offers for transport or transports dangerous goods by aircraft within Canada must do so in accordance with the ICAO Technical Instructions and the provisions of these Regulations referred to in subsection (1).
Despite subsection (2), a person may handle, offer for transport or transport dangerous goods by aircraft within Canada in accordance with the requirements of sections 12.4 to 12.17.

Section.Text: The shipping document for dangerous goods transported by aircraft must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be completed in accordance with Chapter 4, Documentation, of Part 5, Shipper’s Responsibilities, of the ICAO Technical Instructions; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: show the information required for the dangerous goods by the ICAO Technical Instructions on a document that has, on the left and right margins, red hatchings that are oriented to the right or to the left.

Section.Text: Despite subsection 12.1(1), the following text replaces subsection 4.1.6 in section 4.1, Information to the pilot-in-command, of Chapter 4, Provision of information, of Part 7, Operator’s Responsibilities, of the ICAO Technical Instructions:

Provision.Text: “4.1.6 The information provided to the pilot-in-command must be presented on a dedicated form and not by means of air waybills, dangerous goods transport documents, invoices, etc.”

Subsection.Text: A person may handle, offer for transport or transport by aircraft within Canada explosives included in Class 1.4S if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person complies with the ICAO Technical Instructions, other than Part 4, Packing Instructions, and sections 1.1 to 1.3 of Chapter 1, General, sections 2.1 to 2.4.1 and 2.4.3 to 2.5 of Chapter 2, Marking, Chapter 3, Labelling, and Chapter 4, Documentation, of Part 5, Shipper’s Responsibilities;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when the consignor is not the air carrier, the consignor notifies the air carrier of the presence of the explosives before offering them for transport;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the explosives are one or more of the explosives set out in the following table:

row.entry: CARTRIDGES FOR WEAPONS, INERT PROJECTILE, or CARTRIDGES, SMALL ARMS
CARTRIDGES FOR WEAPONS, BLANK, or CARTRIDGES, SMALL ARMS, BLANK, or CARTRIDGES FOR TOOLS, BLANK

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the calibre of cartridges with the UN number UN0012 or UN0014 is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: less than 50 calibres, in the case of cartridges for rifles or pistols, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: greater than or equal to 8 gauge, in the case of cartridges for shotguns;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the gross mass of each means of containment is less than or equal to 25 kg;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the explosives are placed in an inner means of containment that is a box, in metal or plastic clips or in partitions that fit snugly in an outer means of containment that is designed, constructed, filled, closed, secured and maintained so that under normal conditions of transport, including handling, there will be no accidental release of the dangerous goods that could endanger public safety;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the primers are protected from accidental initiation; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: each of the outer means of containment is marked with the gross mass in kilograms and the words “Explosives — Excepted” or “Explosifs — Exceptés”, in letters at least 25 mm high and in a colour that contrasts with the background colour of the means of containment.

Subsection.Text: Despite the restrictions that apply to item 19 of Table 8-1 to Chapter 1, Provisions for dangerous goods carried by passengers or crew, of Part 8, Provisions Concerning Passengers and Crew, of the ICAO Technical Instructions, ammunition, or ammunition loaded in a firearm, with the UN number and shipping name UN0012, CARTRIDGES FOR WEAPONS, INERT PROJECTILE or UN0012, CARTRIDGES, SMALL ARMS or UN0014, CARTRIDGES FOR WEAPONS, BLANK or UN0014, CARTRIDGES, SMALL ARMS, BLANK or UN0014, CARTRIDGES FOR TOOLS, BLANK, may be transported on board an aircraft by a peace officer as defined in section 3 of the Canadian Aviation Security Regulations, 2012, by a Canadian in-flight security officer or by a person described in item 22, column 1, of the table to subsection 78(2) of the Canadian Aviation Security Regulations, 2012.

A person may handle, offer for transport or transport by aircraft within Canada explosives that are forbidden for transport in any of columns 10 to 13 of Table 3-1, Dangerous Goods List, in Chapter 2, Arrangement of the dangerous goods list (Table 3-1), of Part 3, Dangerous Goods List, Special Provisions and Limited and Excepted Quantities, of the ICAO Technical Instructions if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person complies with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraphs 12.1(1)(a) to (j),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the quantity limits and the packing instructions set out in columns 10 to 13 of Table S-3-1, Supplementary Dangerous Goods List, in Chapter 2, Supplementary Dangerous Goods List (Class 1), of Part S-3, Dangerous Goods List, Special Provisions and Quantity Limitations, of the Supplement to the ICAO Technical Instructions, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the requirements of the ICAO Technical Instructions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the explosives are

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: UN0030, DETONATORS, ELECTRIC for blasting,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN0042, BOOSTERS without detonator,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN0059, CHARGES, SHAPED without detonator,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: UN0065, CORD, DETONATING, flexible,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: UN0081, EXPLOSIVE, BLASTING, TYPE A,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN0082, EXPLOSIVE, BLASTING, TYPE B,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN0083, EXPLOSIVE, BLASTING, TYPE C,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN0084, EXPLOSIVE, BLASTING, TYPE D,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: UN0241, EXPLOSIVE, BLASTING, TYPE E,

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: UN0331, EXPLOSIVE, BLASTING, TYPE B; or AGENT, BLASTING, TYPE B,

Subparagraph.Label: (xi)
Subparagraph.Text: UN0332, EXPLOSIVE, BLASTING TYPE E; or AGENT, BLASTING, TYPE E, or

Subparagraph.Label: (xii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN0360, DETONATOR ASSEMBLIES, NON-ELECTRIC for blasting;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the explosives

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: are not included in compatibility group A,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: have not deteriorated or been damaged,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: do not have an active means of initiation and are not primed for use, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: are in a means of containment that is required for them by the packing instructions set out in Chapter 3, Class 1 — Explosives, of Part S-4, Packing Instructions, of the Supplement to the ICAO Technical Instructions; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: there are no other dangerous goods transported on board the aircraft at the same time as the explosives.

Subsection.Text: The consignor of the explosives must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: notify the air carrier, in writing, of the shipping name, UN number, primary class and compatibility group of the explosives at least 48 hours before the explosives are loaded on the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: keep a copy of the notification to the air carrier for two years after the date the notification is sent to the air carrier; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: notify the consignee at least 24 hours before the explosives are transported of the expected time of transport unless the consignor and the air carrier agree that the air carrier will notify the consignee of the expected time of transport when the air carrier gives the consignor written agreement to transport the explosives.

Subsection.Text: The air carrier must, at least 24 hours before transporting the explosives,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: give the consignor written agreement to transport the explosives and keep a copy of this agreement for two years after the date the notification referred to in paragraph (2)(a) is sent to the consignor; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: notify each aerodrome operator listed on the flight plan of the intended time of departure, arrival and technical stops, if any.

Subsection.Text: The notification referred to in paragraph (2)(a) and the agreement referred to in paragraph (3)(a) are valid for any subsequent transport of the explosives for two years beginning on the date that the notification and the agreement were made unless any of the information required in them changes.

A person may handle, offer for transport or transport by aircraft within Canada dangerous goods that are aerosols included in Class 2.1 or 2.2, are UN3175, SOLIDS CONTAINING FLAMMABLE LIQUID, N.O.S., or are included in Class 3 and Packing Group II or III or in Class 6.1 and Packing Group III, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person complies with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraphs 12.1(1)(a) to (j), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the ICAO Technical Instructions, other than Chapter 2, Markings, Chapter 3, Labelling, and Chapter 4, Documentation, of Part 5, Shipper’s Responsibilities, and paragraphs (j) and (l) of Packing Instruction Y963 of Chapter 11, Class 9 — Miscellaneous dangerous goods, of Part 4, Packing Instructions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when the dangerous goods are liquid,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the quantity for Class 3, Packing Group II, is less than or equal to

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: 1 L in a metal inner means of containment, except for UN1263, PAINT or PAINT RELATED MATERIAL, in which case the quantity may be less than or equal to 5 L, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: 500 mL in a glass, earthenware or plastic inner means of containment, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the quantity for Class 3, Packing Group III, and for Class 6.1, Packing Group III, is less than or equal to

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: 5 L in a metal inner means of containment, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: 500 mL in a glass, earthenware or plastic inner means of containment; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: when the dangerous goods are solid, the quantity is less than or equal to 5 kg in an inner means of containment.

Subsection.Text: The person who offers for transport the dangerous goods must, on each small means of containment that contains the dangerous goods,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: mark the words “Air Transport, 12.8, Consumer commodity” or “Transport aérien, 12.8, produit de consommation” in letters at least 25 mm high and in a colour that contrasts with the background colour of the means of containment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for liquids, except flammable liquids in a quantity less than or equal to 120 mL, display on two opposite sides of the means of containment a package orientation label illustrated in Figure 5-29 of Chapter 3, Labelling, of Part 5, Shipper’s Responsibilities, of the ICAO Technical Instructions.

Subsection.Text: Despite subsection (2), the dangerous goods safety marks that are required by that subsection to be marked or displayed on a small means of containment are not required to be marked or displayed on a small means of containment that is inside another small means of containment if the other small means of containment is not opened during loading or unloading or while the dangerous goods are in transport.
An air carrier may handle, offer for transport or transport by aircraft within Canada the dangerous goods referred to in subsections (2) to (12) if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the air carrier complies with subsections (2) to (14);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the air carrier complies with the following requirements in the ICAO Technical Instructions:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: wherever practicable, section 5.1, Information to passengers, of Chapter 5, Provisions concerning passengers and crew, of Part 7, Operator’s Responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 2.4, Loading and securing of dangerous goods, and section 2.5, Damaged packages of dangerous goods, of Chapter 2, Storage and loading, of Part 7, Operator’s Responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: section 3.1, Inspection for damage or leakage, of Chapter 3, Inspection and decontamination, of Part 7, Operator’s Responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: when the person loading or supervising the loading of the dangerous goods on board the aircraft is not a crew member,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: section 4.1, Information to the pilot-in-command, except for packing group, number of packages and identification of the aerodrome, of Chapter 4, Provision of information, of Part 7, Operator’s Responsibilities, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: in the case of dangerous goods transported by helicopter, the information required in clause (A) is provided to a person identified in the air carrier’s Operations Manual rather than the pilot-in-command,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: section 4.2, Information to be provided to employees, of Chapter 4, Provision of information, of Part 7, Operator’s Responsibilities,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: wherever practicable, section 4.8, Cargo acceptance areas — provision of information, of Chapter 4, Provision of information, of Part 7, Operator’s Responsibilities, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: Table 7-1, “Segregation between packages”, of Chapter 2, Storage and loading, of Part 7, Operator’s Responsibilities;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the dangerous goods are

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: transported by cargo aircraft or passenger carrying aircraft referred to in Subpart 4 of Part VI and Subparts 1 to 4 of Part VII of the Canadian Aviation Regulations,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: transported to or from a location where access is limited and there is no other practical or readily available means of transport to transport the dangerous goods, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: contained in a means of containment that has displayed on it the package markings and labels required by Chapter 2, Marking, except for section 2.4.2, and required by Chapter 3, Labelling, except for section 3.2.12, of Part 5, Shipper’s Responsibilities, of the ICAO Technical Instructions;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: when the dangerous goods are Class 2.1, Flammable Gases, or Class 3, Flammable Liquids, smoking is prohibited on board the aircraft and the aircraft and each area or compartment of the aircraft containing the dangerous goods is ventilated to prevent the accumulation of vapours;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: when the dangerous goods are transported on a passenger carrying aircraft, where practicable, they are secured in an area of the aircraft so that they are not readily accessible to the passengers;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the person who handles, offers for transport or transports the dangerous goods is trained in accordance with Part 6 (Training) of these Regulations and Chapter 4, Training, of Part 1, General, of the ICAO Technical Instructions; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the person who has possession of the dangerous goods complies with Part 8 (Reporting Requirements) of these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: The requirements in subsections (3) to (6) apply to dangerous goods that are included in Class 3, Flammable Liquids, and that are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: UN1202, GAS OIL or DIESEL FUEL or HEATING OIL, LIGHT;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: UN1203, GASOLINE or MOTOR SPIRIT or PETROL;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: UN1219, ISOPROPANOL or ISOPROPYL ALCOHOL;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: UN1223, KEROSENE;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: UN1268, PETROLEUM DISTILLATES, N.O.S., or PETROLEUM PRODUCTS, N.O.S., Packing Groups II and III only; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: UN1863, FUEL, AVIATION, TURBINE ENGINE, Packing Groups II and III only.

Subsection.Text: When the Class 3, Flammable Liquids, referred to in subsection (2) are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: contained in a small means of containment that is a drum, the drum must be securely closed and marked with one of the following manufacturer’s permanent markings when the drum has a capacity greater than 25 L and less than or equal to 230 L: TC, CTC, DOT, ICC 5A, 5B, 5C, 17C, 17E, TC-34, CTC-34, DOT-34, UN 1A1, UN 1B1, UN 1H1 or UN 6HA; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: contained in a small means of containment that is not a drum, the small means of containment must be securely closed and

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: marked with one of the following manufacturer’s permanent markings when the small means of containment has a capacity less than or equal to 25 L: UN 3A1, UN 3H1, UL or ULC,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: marked in accordance with ASTM F 852, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: an unmarked steel marine fuel tank of a type that is used to supply fuel for an outboard motor.

Subsection.Text: The following means of containment may be reused to transport the Class 3, Flammable Liquids, referred to in subsection (2):

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a steel drum or jerrican, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: neither the body nor the top or bottom of the drum or jerrican is damaged by wear, scoring, dents or corrosion to the extent that the integrity of the drum or the jerrican is compromised,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any worn or leaking bung caps or seals are replaced,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the top and bottom of the drum are not bulging, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: sufficient ullage is left to ensure that no leakage or permanent distortion will occur as a result of expansion of the liquid caused by any temperature that may be experienced during transport;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a plastic drum or jerrican, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the body of the drum or jerrican is not faded, discoloured, gouged, cracked or distorted to the extent that the integrity of the drum or jerrican is compromised,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the closure flange and bung of the drum show no evidence of cross-threading or thread wear,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: any worn gaskets are replaced, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: when the capacity of the jerrican exceeds 25 L, it is used only for flammable liquids that are included in Packing Group III and that have a flash point greater than 37.8°C; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a steel marine fuel tank, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: neither the body nor the bottom chimes of the tank is damaged by wear, scoring, dents or corrosion to the extent that the integrity of the tank is compromised,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any worn or leaking caps, attachments or seals are replaced, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: sufficient ullage is left to ensure that no leakage or permanent distortion will occur as a result of expansion of the liquid caused by any temperature that may be experienced during transport.

Subsection.Text: When the Class 3, Flammable Liquids, referred to in subsection (2) are contained in a large means of containment, that large means of containment must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a tank, a container or an apparatus that is an integral part of the aircraft or that is attached to the aircraft in accordance with the Certificate of Airworthiness issued under the Canadian Aviation Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a cylindrical collapsible rubber drum that is transported in or suspended from an aircraft and that is constructed, tested, inspected and used in accordance with MIL-D-23119G; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a collapsible fabric tank that is transported suspended from a helicopter and that is constructed of material and seamed in accordance with MIL-T-52983G.

Subsection.Text: When the Class 3, Flammable Liquids, referred to in subsection (2) are transported

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on board a passenger carrying aircraft, the total capacity of all the means of containment must be less than or equal to 230 L; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on board a cargo aircraft, the total capacity of each of the means of containment must be less than or equal to 230 L except for those means of containment referred to in subsection (5).

Heading.TitleText: Internal Combustion Engines, Vehicles and Machinery

Subsection.Text: Dangerous goods that are UN3166, VEHICLE, FLAMMABLE GAS POWERED or UN3166, VEHICLE, FLAMMABLE LIQUID POWERED or UN3166, VEHICLE, FUEL CELL, FLAMMABLE GAS POWERED or UN3166, VEHICLE, FUEL CELL, FLAMMABLE LIQUID POWERED or UN3528, ENGINE, FUEL CELL, FLAMMABLE LIQUID POWERED or UN3528, ENGINE, INTERNAL COMBUSTION, FLAMMABLE LIQUID POWERED or UN3528, MACHINERY, FUEL CELL, FLAMMABLE LIQUID POWERED or UN3528, MACHINERY, INTERNAL COMBUSTION, FLAMMABLE LIQUID POWERED or UN3529, ENGINE, FUEL CELL, FLAMMABLE GAS POWERED or UN3529, ENGINE, INTERNAL COMBUSTION, FLAMMABLE GAS POWERED or UN3529, MACHINERY, FUEL CELL, FLAMMABLE GAS POWERED or UN3529, MACHINERY, INTERNAL COMBUSTION, FLAMMABLE GAS POWERED or UN3530, ENGINE, INTERNAL COMBUSTION or UN3530, MACHINERY, INTERNAL COMBUSTION must be handled, offered for transport or transported in accordance with the following requirements of the ICAO Technical Instructions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Special Provision A87 of Chapter 3, Special provisions, of Part 3, Dangerous Goods List, Special Provisions and Limited and Excepted Quantities;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Instruction 950 of Chapter 11, Class 9 — Miscellaneous dangerous goods, of Part 4, Packing Instructions, in the case of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3166, VEHICLE, FLAMMABLE LIQUID POWERED, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3166, VEHICLE, FUEL CELL, FLAMMABLE LIQUID POWERED;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Instruction 951 of Chapter 11, Class 9 — Miscellaneous dangerous goods, of Part 4, Packing Instructions, in the case of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3166, VEHICLE, FLAMMABLE GAS POWERED, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3166, VEHICLE, FUEL CELL, FLAMMABLE GAS POWERED;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Instruction 378 of Chapter 5, Class 3 — Flammable liquids, of Part 4, Packing Instructions, in the case of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3528, ENGINE, INTERNAL COMBUSTION, FLAMMABLE LIQUID POWERED,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3528, ENGINE, FUEL CELL, FLAMMABLE LIQUID POWERED,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3528, MACHINERY, FUEL CELL, FLAMMABLE LIQUID POWERED, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3528, MACHINERY, INTERNAL COMBUSTION, FLAMMABLE LIQUID POWERED;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Instruction 220 of Chapter 4, Class 2 — Gases, of Part 4, Packing Instructions, in the case of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3529, ENGINE, INTERNAL COMBUSTION, FLAMMABLE GAS POWERED,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3529, ENGINE, FUEL CELL, FLAMMABLE GAS POWERED,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3529, MACHINERY, FUEL CELL, FLAMMABLE GAS POWERED, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3529, MACHINERY, INTERNAL COMBUSTION, FLAMMABLE GAS POWERED; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: Packing Instruction 972 of Chapter 11, Class 9 — Miscellaneous dangerous goods, of Part 4, Packing Instructions, in the case of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3530, ENGINE, INTERNAL COMBUSTION, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: UN3530, MACHINERY, INTERNAL COMBUSTION.

Subsection.Text: When dangerous goods are UN1044, FIRE EXTINGUISHERS, Class 2.2, they must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be in compliance with section 5.10 of Part 5 (Means of Containment);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have a capacity less than or equal to 18 L when they are transported on board a passenger carrying aircraft; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be packed in accordance with Packing Instruction 213 of Chapter 4, Class 2 — Gases, of Part 4, Packing Instructions, of the ICAO Technical Instructions.

Subsection.Text: The following dangerous goods that are included in Class 2.1, Flammable Gases, must be in a means of containment set out in subsection (10):

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: UN1011, BUTANE;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: UN1012, BUTYLENE;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: UN1055, ISOBUTYLENE;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: UN1075, LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GASES;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: UN1077, PROPYLENE;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: UN1969, ISOBUTANE; or

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: UN1978, PROPANE.

Subsection.Text: The dangerous goods referred to in subsection (9) must be contained in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a means of containment that is marked TC-51, DOT-51 or CTC-51 and that is in standard with CSA B622 and Appendices A and B of CSA B620; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a cylinder that is in compliance with section 5.10 of Part 5 (Means of Containment), and

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the cylinder has a capacity less than or equal to 100 L,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the dangerous goods are transported in cylinders on board a passenger carrying aircraft, the total capacity of all the cylinders must be less than or equal to 120 L, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the cylinder is secured in an upright position or in as near an upright position as possible to prevent movement during transport.

Subsection.Text: Dangerous goods that are UN2794, BATTERIES, WET, FILLED WITH ACID, Class 8, UN2795, BATTERIES, WET, FILLED WITH ALKALI, Class 8, or UN2800, BATTERIES, WET, NON-SPILLABLE, Class 8, must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be transported in accordance with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the third sentence of Special Provision A123 of Chapter 3, Special provisions, of Part 3, Dangerous Goods List, Special Provisions and Limited and Excepted Quantities, of the ICAO Technical Instructions, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the following packing instructions of Chapter 10, Class 8 — Corrosives, of Part 4, Packing Instructions, of the ICAO Technical Instructions, except that, when the aircraft is not a pressurized aircraft, section 1.1.6 of Chapter 1, General packing requirements, of Part 4, Packing Instructions, of the ICAO Technical Instructions does not apply:

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: for batteries with the UN number UN2794 or UN2795, Packing Instruction 870, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: for batteries with the UN number UN2800, Packing Instruction 872; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the batteries are transported on board a passenger carrying aircraft, have a gross mass less than or equal to 120 kg.

Subsection.Text: When dangerous goods are UN1496, SODIUM CHLORITE, Class 5.1, or UN1791, HYPOCHLORITE SOLUTION, Class 8,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the available chlorine must be 7% or less;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of the dangerous goods in an inner means of containment must be less than or equal to 5 L or 5 kg and, in an outer means of containment must be less than or equal to 20 L or 20 kg;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the dangerous goods must be placed in a leakproof inner means of containment that is a combination packaging, as defined in Chapter 3, General information, of Part 1, General, of the ICAO Technical Instructions; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the inner means of containment must be placed in an outer means of containment that is designed, constructed, filled, closed, secured and maintained so that under normal conditions of transport, including handling, there will be no accidental release of the dangerous goods that could endanger public safety.

Subsection.Text: An air carrier must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command of an aircraft, other than a helicopter, transporting dangerous goods

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: briefs flight attendants, if any, on the nature and location of the dangerous goods that are in any compartment to which the flight attendants have access, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: completes and signs a manifest, journey log or flight record, or any other type of document designated for this purpose in the Operator’s Manual, that includes the shipping name, UN number, class and quantity of dangerous goods transported that day;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at the end of each day, the pilot-in-command of a helicopter transporting dangerous goods completes and signs a manifest, journey log or flight record or any other type of document designated for this purpose in the Operator’s Manual, that includes the words “Dangerous Goods Transported” or “Marchandises dangereuses transportées”;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the air carrier keeps the documents referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b) for 12 months after the date on which the dangerous goods are no longer in transport; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: when an in-flight emergency occurs and circumstances permit, the pilot-in-command

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: complies with section 4.3, Information to be provided by the pilot-in-command in case of in-flight emergency, of Chapter 4, Provision of information, of Part 7, Operator’s Responsibilities, of the ICAO Technical Instructions, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: for an external load of dangerous goods suspended from a helicopter, notifies the appropriate air traffic services unit that dangerous goods are in the external load.

Subsection.Text: An air carrier must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the consignor, the person who accepts the dangerous goods or the person who loads the aircraft is not an employee of the air carrier, keep the following information for 12 months after the date on which the dangerous goods are no longer in transport:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the name and address of each consignor of dangerous goods, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the name and address of the person who

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: accepts each consignment of dangerous goods or directly supervises the acceptance of the dangerous goods, or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: loads and secures the dangerous goods or directly supervises the loading and securing of the dangerous goods;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: keep a copy of the information referred to in clause (1)(b)(iv)(A) for 12 months after the date on which the dangerous goods are no longer in transport; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for transport by helicopter, ensure that the following information is prepared before the dangerous goods are transported and is kept for 12 months after the date on which the dangerous goods are no longer in transport:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the name and address of each consignor of dangerous goods,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the approximate date of transport,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the locations to and from which the dangerous goods are to be transported,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the shipping name, the UN number, the class and the quantity of dangerous goods to be transported, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the name of the air carrier’s employee who prepares the information.

Subsection.Text: An air carrier must produce a record, notice or report required by subsection (1) within 15 days after the day on which a written request is received from an inspector.

Section.Text: A person may handle or transport dangerous goods within Canada by small aircraft or helicopter registered as private aircraft under sections 202.16 and 202.17 of the Canadian Aviation Regulations if the dangerous goods

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are intended for non-commercial recreational use; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are not forbidden for transport by Schedule 1 or Schedule 3 to these Regulations or by the ICAO Technical Instructions.

Section.Text: A person may handle, offer for transport or transport by aircraft within Canada dangerous goods that are contained in geological core samples less than or equal to 100 mm in diameter if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when the consignor is not the air carrier, the consignor notifies the air carrier of the presence of the core samples before offering them for transport;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the core samples are transported in wooden core sample boxes that are wrapped in a sealed plastic or polyethylene bag or in a means of containment that is equally leak-proof;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the core samples as well as the means of containment are secured to prevent movement during transport; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the core samples contain radioactive material, they are contained in a means of containment in accordance with the Packaging and Transport of Nuclear Substances Regulations.

Subsection.Text: A person may handle, offer for transport or transport dangerous goods by aircraft within Canada if the dangerous goods are being used at the location where the following aerial work takes place:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: active fire suppression;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: aerial cloud seeding;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: aerial drip torching;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: agriculture;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: avalanche control;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: forestry;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: horticulture;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: hydrographic or seismographic work; or

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: pollution control.

Subsection.Text: The dangerous goods must be contained in a means of containment that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a tank, a container or an apparatus that is an integral part of the aircraft or that is attached to the aircraft in accordance with the Certificate of Airworthiness issued under the Canadian Aviation Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a cylindrical collapsible rubber drum that is transported in or suspended from an aircraft and that is constructed, tested, inspected and used in accordance with MIL-D-23119G;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a collapsible fabric tank that is transported suspended from a helicopter and that is constructed of material and seamed in accordance with MIL-T-52983G; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a small means of containment designed, constructed, filled, closed, secured and maintained so that under normal conditions of transport, including handling, there will be no accidental release of the dangerous goods that could endanger public safety.

Subsection.Text: The air carrier must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person who loads and secures the dangerous goods on board the aircraft is trained, or works under the direct supervision of a person who is trained, in accordance with Part 6 (Training) of these Regulations and Chapter 4, Training, of Part 1, General, of the ICAO Technical Instructions;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the dangerous goods are handled or transported by a person other than an employee of the air carrier, that person is trained in accordance with Part 6 (Training) of these Regulations and Chapter 4, Training, of Part 1, General, of the ICAO Technical Instructions;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the air carrier complies with Part 8 (Reporting Requirements) of these Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the pilot-in-command of the aircraft does not load or directly supervise the loading of the dangerous goods, the person who loads and secures the dangerous goods gives the pilot-in-command, in writing, the following information for each of the dangerous goods:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: its shipping name, UN number and class, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the gross mass of the dangerous goods and, in the case of explosives, the net explosives quantity;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: smoking is prohibited on board the aircraft and each area or compartment of the aircraft containing dangerous goods is ventilated to prevent the accumulation of vapour;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: when an in-flight emergency occurs and circumstances permit, the pilot-in-command complies with section 4.3, Information to be provided by the pilot-in-command in case of in-flight emergency, of Chapter 4, Provision of information, of Part 7, Operator’s Responsibilities, of the ICAO Technical Instructions; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the person who loads and secures or directly supervises the loading and securing of dangerous goods on board the aircraft

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: complies with section 3.1, Inspection for damage or leakage, of Chapter 3, Inspection and decontamination, of Part 7, Operator’s Responsibilities, of the ICAO Technical Instructions, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: segregates the means of containment that contain dangerous goods that could react dangerously with one another in case of a release, in accordance with Table 7-1, “Segregation between packages”, of Chapter 2, Storage and loading, of Part 7, Operator’s Responsibilities, of the ICAO Technical Instructions.

Section.Text: A person may handle or transport by aircraft within Canada a measuring instrument that contains dangerous goods if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person who is responsible for the measuring instrument

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: ensures that the measuring instrument or its means of containment has displayed on it labels in accordance with Chapter 3, Labelling, of Part 5, Shipper’s Responsibilities, of the ICAO Technical Instructions,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: before transporting the measuring instrument on the aircraft, has the written agreement of the air carrier to use or transport the measuring instrument on board the aircraft, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: is trained in accordance with Part 6 (Training) of these Regulations and Chapter 4, Training, of Part 1, General, of the ICAO Technical Instructions and complies with all laws applicable to the measuring instrument;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the measuring instrument is placed or used in a location in the aircraft that is known to the pilot-in-command and the flight crew; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: when the measuring instrument contains radioactive materials,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the radiation level at 100 mm from any point of the external surface of the instrument is less than or equal to 100 µSv/h (10 millirems per hour), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the activity of the measuring instrument does not exceed the applicable exception limit set out in the column entitled “Item limits” in Table 2-14, “Activity limits for excepted packages”, of Chapter 7, Class 7 — Radioactive material, of Part 2, Classification of Dangerous Goods, of the ICAO Technical Instructions.

Subsection.Text: A person may handle, offer for transport or transport by aircraft within Canada dangerous goods, other than Class 2, Gases, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the dangerous goods will be used or part of the dangerous goods have been used for a person who will require or who has required medical aid during flight;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the transport of the dangerous goods is not forbidden by Schedule 1 or Schedule 3 of these Regulations or the ICAO Technical Instructions;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: before the dangerous goods are loaded, the person who offers them for transport receives the agreement of the air carrier to transport the dangerous goods on board the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the air carrier

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: directly supervises the loading and securing of the dangerous goods on board the aircraft so that they do not move during transport,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: complies with section 3.1, Inspection for damage or leakage, of Chapter 3, Inspection and decontamination, of Part 7, Operator’s Responsibilities, of the ICAO Technical Instructions, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: provides to the pilot-in-command, in writing, the shipping name, the UN number and the class of the dangerous goods and their location on board the aircraft;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in the event of a change of aircraft or flight crew, the pilot-in-command communicates the information required by subparagraph (d)(iii) to the next pilot-in-command;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the air carrier’s employees are trained, or work under the direct supervision of a person who is trained, in accordance with Part 6 (Training) of these Regulations and Chapter 4, Training, of Part 1, General, of the ICAO Technical Instructions; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the air carrier complies with Part 8 (Reporting Requirements) of these Regulations.

Subsection.Text: The air carrier and the person who offers the dangerous goods for transport must ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the dangerous goods are contained in a means of containment that is designed, constructed, filled, closed, secured and maintained so that under normal conditions of transport, including handling, there will be no accidental release of the dangerous goods that could endanger public safety; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the means of containment has displayed on it the package markings and labels required by Chapter 2, Marking, and Chapter 3, Labelling, of Part 5, Shipper’s Responsibilities, of the ICAO Technical Instructions.

Subsection.Text: A person may handle, offer for transport or transport by aircraft within Canada UN1072, OXYGEN, COMPRESSED, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the air carrier and the person who offers the dangerous goods for transport comply with the requirements of subsection (1) and paragraph (2)(b);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the dangerous goods are in a cylinder that is in compliance with section 5.10 of Part 5 (Means of Containment) of these Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: each cylinder contains a quantity of UN1072, OXYGEN, COMPRESSED, that is less than or equal to 850 L or 30 ft3;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the number of cylinders containing UN1072, OXYGEN, COMPRESSED, does not exceed 6 owned by the air carrier and one additional cylinder for each passenger who needs the oxygen at destination; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command is advised of the number of cylinders loaded on board the aircraft.

Section.Text: A person may handle or transport within Canada, by an aircraft that does not have a Class B, Class C or Class D cargo compartment, dangerous goods other than those included in Class 4.3, Water Reactive Substances, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person complies with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: paragraphs 12.1(1)(a) to (j), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the ICAO Technical Instructions, other than section 2.1, Loading restrictions on flight deck and for passenger aircraft, of Chapter 2, Storage and loading, of Part 7, Operator’s Responsibilities;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a certificate was issued for the aircraft under Subpart 4 of Part VI or Subpart 3 or 4 of Part VII of the Canadian Aviation Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: transport of the dangerous goods is not forbidden by Schedule 1 or Schedule 3 of these Regulations or the ICAO Technical Instructions;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: transport of the dangerous goods is not restricted by the ICAO Technical Instructions to cargo aircraft only; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the dangerous goods are loaded and transported in a compartment that is accessible during flight so that the dangerous goods and any other cargo can be readily reached by a crew member using, if necessary, a hand-held fire extinguisher.

Heading.TitleText: Effective Date and Expiry of a Protective Direction

Subsection.Text: A protective direction takes effect on the date on which it is signed by the Minister or at a later date indicated in the protective direction. However, after the effective date of the protective direction, any non-compliance with it must not be enforced against a person unless the person has received the original signed protective direction or an electronic copy of it, or reasonable steps have been taken to make the person aware of the protective direction.
A protective direction expires on the expiry date specified in it. If no expiry date is specified in the protective direction, it expires 12 months after the date on which it is signed.

Heading.TitleText: Requesting a Review of a Protective Direction

Subsection.Text: A person may request a review of a protective direction at any time after it is signed.
The request must be made, in writing, to the Minister and must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the place of business of the person requesting the review;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the result the person expects from the review; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all the information necessary to support the request for the review.

Section.Text: A person must apply to the Minister in writing for an equivalency certificate and must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the applicant is an individual, the name of the individual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the applicant is a company or an association, the name of the company or association and each association member, as the names appear in letters patent, articles of incorporation or any other document that shows the legal identity of the company or the association and each association member;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the address of the place of business of the applicant;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the telephone number, including the area code, and, if applicable, the electronic mailing address and the facsimile number of the applicant;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if a person submits an application on behalf of a company or an association, the person’s name and position and the telephone number, including the area code, and address of the person’s place of business;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the classification of the dangerous goods and, if the dangerous goods are in a solution or mixture, the composition and percentage (specified by volume, mass or net explosives quantity) of each chemical;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the method of packaging the dangerous goods, including a description of the means of containment and the quantity of dangerous goods in each means of containment;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: whether the equivalency certificate is requested for transport by road vehicle, railway vehicle, aircraft or vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the proposal for an equivalency certificate, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the requirements of the Act or these Regulations that the applicant proposes not to comply with,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the manner in which the activity will be carried out and how that manner will provide a level of safety at least equivalent to that provided by compliance with the Act and these Regulations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: drawings, plans, calculations, procedures, test results and any other information necessary to support the proposal;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the length of time or the schedule of activities for which the equivalency certificate is requested; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the name, position and business telephone number, including the area code, of the person who can be contacted regarding the application for an equivalency certificate and who is authorized by the applicant to speak on the applicant’s behalf.

Heading.TitleText: Issuance or Refusal of an Equivalency Certificate

Section.Text: If an application for an equivalency certificate is refused, the Minister must notify the applicant, in writing, of the refusal and the reasons for the refusal.

Heading.TitleText: Applying for Renewal of an Equivalency Certificate

Section.Text: A person must apply to the Minister in writing to renew an equivalency certificate and must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the applicant is an individual, the name of the individual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the applicant is a company or an association, the name of the company or association and each association member, as the names appear in letters patent, articles of incorporation or any other document that shows the legal identity of the company or the association and each association member;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the address of the place of business of the applicant;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the telephone number, including the area code, and, if applicable, the electronic mailing address and the facsimile number of the applicant;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if a person submits an application on behalf of a company or an association, the person’s name and position and the telephone number, including the area code, and address of the person’s place of business;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: certification that the information provided in the original application in accordance with paragraphs 14.1(f) to (i) is still applicable and complete;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the length of time or the schedule of activities for which the renewal is requested; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the name, position and business telephone number, including the area code, of the person who can be contacted regarding the application for a renewal and who is authorized by the applicant to speak on the applicant’s behalf.

Heading.TitleText: Renewal or Refusal of a Renewal of an Equivalency Certificate

Subsection.Text: The Minister may renew an equivalency certificate if the Minister is satisfied, on the basis of the information available and the information submitted with the application for a renewal, that the activity authorized by the equivalency certificate will provide a level of safety at least equivalent to that provided by compliance with the Act and these Regulations.
If an application for a renewal is refused, the Minister must notify the applicant, in writing, of the refusal and the reasons for the refusal.

Section.Text: The Minister must notify a person, in writing, of the revocation of an equivalency certificate under subsection 31(6) of the Act and the reasons for the revocation.

Heading.TitleText: Requesting a Review of a Decision to Refuse or Revoke an Equivalency Certificate

Subsection.Text: A person may request a review of a decision to refuse or revoke an equivalency certificate within 30 days after the day on which the notification of the decision is received.
The request must be made in writing to the Minister and must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the place of business of the person requesting the review;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons why the decision should be reversed; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all of the information necessary to support the request for the review.

Heading.TitleText: Processing a Request for a Review

Section.Text: The Minister may issue an equivalency certificate that was refused or reissue an equivalency certificate that was revoked if the Minister is satisfied, on the basis of the information available and the information submitted with the request for review, that the activity authorized by the equivalency certificate will provide a level of safety at least equivalent to that provided by compliance with the Act and these Regulations.
The Minister must notify, in writing, the person who made the request for a review of the decision and the reasons for the decision.
A person who is subject to a court order that requires payment of an amount of money under paragraph 34(1)(d) of the Act to be used to conduct programs of research must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide a summary of the order, in writing, to the Minister within 30 days after the day on which the order is made; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: give to the Minister the amount in the form of a certified cheque, money order or bank draft, payable to the Receiver General for Canada, within the period established by the court or, if no period is established, within 90 days after the day on which the order is made.

Section.Text: A certificate of designation issued to an inspector under subsection 10(2) of the Act must be in the following form:

row.entry: Area of qualification / Domaine de compétence

entry.Language: This person is designated as an inspector for the purposes of the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992.
Cette personne est désignée à titre d’inspecteur pour l’application de la Loi de 1992 sur le transport des marchandises dangereuses.

Section.Text: An inspection certificate provided under subsection 11(1) of the Act when an inspector opens anything for inspection or takes a sample of anything that is sealed or closed up must be in the following form:

row.entry: Date of Activity / Date de l’activité
Activity (inspection or sample taking) / Activité (visite ou prise d’échantillon)
Quantity of Sample / Quantité de l’échantillon
Date Resealed / Date d’apposition du nouveau plomb
Seal Number, if any / Numéro du plomb, le cas échéant

Provision.Text: Name / Signature / Certificate Number of Inspector

Text.Language: Nom / Signature / Numéro du certificat de l’inspecteur

Heading.TitleText: Detention of Dangerous Goods or Means of Containment

Subsection.Text: When an inspector detains dangerous goods or a means of containment under subsection 17(1) or (2) of the Act, the inspector must deliver a Detention Notice in the form following this section to the person who has charge, management or control of the dangerous goods or of the means of containment at the time they are detained.
The inspector must sign and date the Notice.

The detention takes effect when the Notice is signed and dated by the inspector. However, any non-compliance with the detention must not be enforced against a person until the person has received the Notice or a copy of it or a reasonable attempt has been made to give the person the Notice or a copy of it.
The detention expires 12 months after the day on which it takes effect, but it may be revoked earlier, in writing, by an inspector.

A person may request a review of the detention at any time after it takes effect and the Notice is delivered to the person who has charge, management or control of the dangerous goods or of the means of containment. The request must be made in writing to the Minister or the Director General and must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the place of business of the person requesting the review;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the Notice;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons why the detention should be revoked; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all of the information necessary to support the request for the review.

Subsection.Text: The Minister or the Director General must notify the person, in writing, of the decision made and the reasons for the decision.

entry.Emphasis: Detention Notice

row.entry: Subsection 17(1) or (2) of the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992

entry.Emphasis: Notice Number:
File Number:

The dangerous goods described in this Notice are not being handled, offered for transport, transported or imported in compliance with the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992 and the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations. They are detained until an inspector is satisfied that the dangerous goods will be handled, offered for transport, transported or imported in compliance with the Act and the Regulations.

The standardized means of containment described in this Notice are not being sold, offered for sale, delivered, distributed, imported or used in compliance with the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992 and the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations. They are detained until an inspector is satisfied that the means of containment will be sold, offered for sale, delivered, distributed, imported or used in compliance with the Act and the Regulations.

In accordance with paragraph 13(1)(c) of the Act, a person must not remove, alter or interfere in any way with dangerous goods or the means of containment detained by an inspector unless authorized by an inspector.
Person Receiving the Notice
(include name and position of the person, company name, address of place of business, postal code, telephone number, fax number, e-mail address)
Inspector Issuing the Notice
(include name, address of place of business, postal code, telephone number, fax number, e-mail address, certificate of designation number)
Date the Notice is Issued
(dd/mm/yyyy)
Description of the Dangerous Goods
(include UN number, shipping name, primary class, subsidiary class, packing group)
Description of the Means of Containment
(include serial number)
Details of Non-compliance
(include references to the Act and Regulations)

SignatureName.Emphasis: Release of Dangerous Goods or Means of Containment

entry.Emphasis: The undersigned is satisfied that the dangerous goods described in this Notice will be handled, offered for transport, transported or imported in compliance with the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992 and the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations and hereby releases the dangerous goods.

The undersigned is satisfied that the means of containment described in this Notice will be sold, offered for sale, delivered, distributed, imported or used in compliance with the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992 and the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations, and hereby releases the means of containment.

Subsection.Text: When an inspector directs a person, under subsection 17(3) of the Act, to take necessary measures to remedy non-compliance with the Act and these Regulations, the inspector must deliver to that person a Notice of Direction to Remedy Non-compliance in the form following this section.
The inspector must sign and date the Notice.

The Notice must also be signed and dated by one of the following designated persons before it is delivered to the person directed by the inspector to take the necessary measures: the Director, Compliance and Response, the Chief, Response Operations, or the Chief, Enforcement, of the Transport Dangerous Goods Directorate, Department of Transport.

The direction takes effect when the Notice is signed and dated in accordance with subsections (2) and (3). However, any non-compliance with the direction must not be enforced against a person until the person has received the Notice or a copy of it or a reasonable attempt has been made to give the person the Notice or a copy of it.
The direction expires 12 months after the day on which it takes effect, but it may be revoked earlier, in writing, by an inspector.

A person may request a review of the direction at any time after it takes effect and the Notice is delivered to the person who has charge, management or control of the dangerous goods or means of containment. The request must be made in writing to the Minister or the Director General and must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the place of business of the person requesting the review;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the Notice;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons why the direction should be revoked; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all of the information necessary to support the request for the review.

Subsection.Text: The Minister or the Director General must notify the person, in writing, of the decision made and the reasons for the decision.

entry.Emphasis: NOTICE OF DIRECTION TO REMEDY NON-COMPLIANCE
Delivered to persons directed by an inspector to take measures under subsection 17(3) of the Act to remedy non-compliance with the Act and Regulations.
Person Receiving the Notice

Details of Non-compliance
(including reference to the Act and Regulations)
Inspector’s Direction to Remedy Non-compliance
Revocation
(include reasons for justifying the revocation, name, title and signature of person revoking the direction)

Heading.TitleText: Direction Not to Import or to Return to Place of Origin

Subsection.Text: When an inspector directs, under subsection 17(4) of the Act, a person who has charge, management or control of dangerous goods or means of containment that the dangerous goods or means of containment not be imported into Canada or, if they are already in Canada, that they be returned to their place of origin, the inspector must deliver to that person a Notice of Direction Not to Import or to Return to Place of Origin in the form following this section.
The inspector must sign and date the Notice.

The direction takes effect when the Notice is signed and dated by the inspector. However, any non-compliance with the direction must not be enforced against a person until the person has received the Notice or a copy of it or a reasonable attempt has been made to give the person the Notice or a copy of it.
The direction expires 12 months after the day on which it takes effect, but it may be revoked earlier, in writing, by an inspector.

A person may request a review of the direction at any time after it takes effect and the Notice is delivered to the person who has charge, management or control of the dangerous goods or means of containment. The request must be made in writing to the Minister or the Director General and must include the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the place of business of the person requesting the review;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the Notice;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons why the direction should be revoked; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all of the information necessary to support the request for the review.

Subsection.Text: The Minister or the Director General must notify the person, in writing, of the decision made and the reasons for the decision.

entry.Emphasis: NOTICE OF DIRECTION NOT TO IMPORT OR TO RETURN TO PLACE OF ORIGIN
Subsection 17(4) of the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992

The dangerous goods or the means of containment described in this Notice are not being handled, offered for transport, transported or imported in compliance with the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992, and are directed not to be imported or to be returned to the place of origin.
